description: Yummy, great find on a crazy business trip. The selection was very enticing and hard to choose from. Every dish we tried was good.  The decor is a bit tired, and the water tasted off, kinda like an pan smells when oil is baked on, weird. But, the food tasted wonderful! The staff were very friendly and helpful.  I will consider going another time too.
author: Klee L.

description:
OK, being Chinese, when you walk into a Dim Sum restaurant for lunch and not many tables are occupied and the ones that are, are all Americans... I get a little nervous. My dining partner and I had a flight to catch and wanted to get our last Dim Sum fix in before heading to the airport. The restaurant is on a second level, we were greeted and seated by the hostess (?owner).

Up front I will say the service was very very good, We ordered: Beers, Spicy Salt Shell Prawns, Shrimp Dumplings, Shrimp and Chive Dumplings and BBQ Steamed Buns. The food came out hot and fresh and tasted good. I'm glad I tried this new place for us. Would I go back, maybe... but with so many other choices???

Atmosphere: nicer than most typical Chinatown restaurants. Service: very good, Food: good.
author: Melody K.

description:
Friendly service, they can easily handle large groups.
You must get the bird's nest, it is wonderfully crispy Birdsnest held succulent seafood in a delightful sauce.
author: Deborah B.

description: Looks super janky when you first walk in but then you turn the corner and it opens up to a very nice clean place. The service and food were really fast...and great!!! The chow mein noodles were thin and not too greasy, the honey walnut shrimp was to die for and the Mongolia beef had a nice sweetness to it. Really great place that was recommended by some random guy on the street. I'm so happy we took a chance
author: Nicole A.

description:
The service was great! The food was good. 
Walking in, the outside looks like a hole in the wall, but you walk up a flight of stairs and all of a sudden it opens up into a nice good sized restaurant! I came for lunch with a friend on a Friday. We ordered the dim sum lunch for 2. It had all the items that you would want, and you don't have to hail a cart over! The pork buns were good, but nothing totally stood out to me.
author: Lindsey P.

description: Food was ok.  The SERVICE was terrible! They spilled tea and food on our table and on my iPhone. Never come to the table to ask us how the food was or if we needed anything else.. NEVER recommend this place again!!
author: Vaishali V.

description: I love spicy Chinese and they have not here. The dim sum assortment were heavy and though yummy not of high quality.  Also had salt fish and a hot chicken dish recommended by server. The heat and salt were intense but not matched by again, the weight of the batter on the fish and some of the gristle in the dark meat chicken.
author: Diane F.

description: My family and I went to the Oriental Pearl on a whim while exploring China Town during their visit.  The staff was really friendly!  The food was really tasty... I'm  used to fast food take out Chinese.  This was definitely fresh and better quality.  It was a real treat for my out of town guests!  The iced tea is really tasty too!
author: Javier P.

description:
We went here for the Peking Duck, one of my all time favorite meals. 

Right in the heart of Chinatown, it's a bit classier than most, a safe place to take anyone as the decor is upscale, service is professional and the ambience is that of a higher end establishment. There was a ton of tourists and we were the only Asian people dining, even as it got full to capacity around 8pm on a Saturday night.

The Peking Duck was good, they make the pancakes for you, complete with sauce, cucumbers, scallions and carrots. I didn't like it that they did not present the duck and slice it in front of the table, and I like to roll my own pancakes. At almost sixty bucks, it was on the expensive side but I guess it is a tourist place.

There was this "decorative" vase made entirely of veggies that came with the duck, very pretty with the vase made of taro and the flowers made of celery, carrots, ginger and cucumber. You can't eat It though, and neither can you take it home. Strange.
author: Alex C.

description:
Date: 7/11/2017  Time: 1:05 PM  68°  Sunny

After the tour of the Asian Art Museum, our group from the Mastick Senior Center headed to the Oriental Pearl Restaurant for a dim sum lunch. Location of this restaurant is on Clay Street, about 1/2 block from Portsmouth Square. The restaurant is on the second level. One can either take the elevator or walk up the stairs. The name of the restaurant sounds a bit cheesy to me. Is this restaurant more of an attraction for tourists having a first time experience with a dim sum lunch?

Ambiance: nice for a restaurant of its size. Some artwork mounted on one of the walls. Lovely floral arrangements on the credenza. 

The host and employees are attentive and pleasant. I even spoke a few words in Cantonese to them. They filled our water glasses and brought pots of tea without us asking. Service was prompt. A fixed menu was on the lazy susan at each table. 

Some of the dim sum (egg roll, shrimp dumpling aka har gow and potsticker) were pretty good. The remaining ones were small in size (chicken cilantro, beef dumpling, Shanghai style pork dumpling). The vegetable fried rice was slightly bland. The chicken chow mein was edible...not greasy, which was a good thing. For dessert we had sweet sesame ball, fortune cookie and mint candy. I don't know what happened with the bean paste filling inside the sweet sesame ball. It was lacking in a flavor of sweetness.

Inasmuch as I would like to give them a four star rating for their ambiance, service and some of the dim sum, I walked away not totally impressed with the tiny dumplings. The sweet sesame ball was a disappointment. I can only say it must be the Chinese in me to say I had better dim sum elsewhere in both San Francisco and Oakland Chinatown (restaurants and bakeries). 

Because lunch was part of a tour for us senior citizens at a cost of $62 per person, I don't know what percentage of the cost was for transportation, admission to the Asian Art Museum and lunch. It has left me somewhat pondering whether the lunch was worth the value.
author: Carol C.

description:
Here's another fine spot in China Town. Yes an another referral to this fine restaurant. The service is impeccable and the food is fresh and delicious. 
I definitely have Oriental Pearl bookmarked!
author: Bruce B.

description: So I'm in San Francisco. What to eat what to eat? I ask the girl behind the counter at the hotel where to eat Chinese.  Can't skip the chance to visit Chinatown.  She said go here and here I go. I order the Clay pot salted fish, tofu and minced pork. Not bad. Not great. I'm at a 2.5 but no such thing so a 3 it is by default
author: Mike G.

description: I ordered the prawns with peanuts and was a tad disappointed on the size of the shrimp. They were shrimp and not prawns in my humble opinion. The brown sause with peanuts was tasty.  We ordered hot and sour soup for the table and there was enough for one serving each of the four of us.  My wife ordered the braised spicy ribs and was a little disappointed in the lack of meat on the ribs but I thought it was fine. Others got the sweet and sour chicken and it was delicious. The birds nest was exceptional. The seafood in that dish was fresh and plentiful. Overall a nice dinner.
author: Thomas M.

description: We have eaten here twice, several years apart. Both times were excellent. We were surprised that they were not busier, we were a party of 4 and got right in. Service was very attentive. Food was excellent. I can't see why you'd wait an hour at a place with a health code WARNING on their yelp page when you could eat here. Great value, great experience. Highly recommend it. We will be back next time we are in the area.
author: Shannon F.

description:
Authentic and delicious dim sum and Chinese food. After being in town for business I needed to have lunch and decided to look around Chinatown for son Har Gaw (shrimp Dim sum) found it!

Also saw that they had a nice lunch menu served until 2 pm with entree rice and soup for around $9 give or take. 

The food is very good and fresh. The service is friendly and prompt. They were quick to greet me at the door. The ambiance is nicer than most places in Chinatown and the health score is over 92!! This is a huge plus in the area. As I did notice some of the restaurants had very bad health scores which made me not want to go anywhere else. When I'm the area and wanting a great Chinese meal, try oriental pearl!
author: Roxanne R.

description: Absolutely amazing.  So much food that we swore we wouldn't eat all of yet we destroyed it all.  Not overly seasoned and outstanding.  I will go back and try more dishes.
author: Bryan G.

description: Our first night in San Francisco, and my friend and I were given a recommendation to this Chinatown restaurant by our concierge. From the exterior, you may think twice about going in, but upstairs the restaurant unfolds to a lovely space. We did not have reservations, but were seated promptly. The food was delicious. Full bar service. And although the staff was attentive, we felt very rushed to give up our table towards the end of our meal.
author: Missy T.

description:
I went here on the recommendation of a friend, and I must say I'm surprised. I'm sure SF has no shortage of great dim sum (and Cantonese food in general), but I ordered my three usuals and was rather pleased with them all.

eats:
shu mai
har gow
rice paper rolls with shrimp

Rice paper rolls are basically the same everywhere, but I was pleasantly surprised with the har gow and shu mai, especially the shu mai. The flavors were incredible. I would definitely return.

They were out of egg custards which I was sad about, but I went at a weird time and my rating in no way reflects this.
author: Mai-Anh H.

description: Wonderful meal!  Concierge recommended this place and he was right about it!  Great service and excellent fresh food. Chicken meatballs (their specialty) were very good!
author: Nina Y.

description: 3.5 stars. Dim sum is 4 stars, but the service is slowwwwwww. This place is a hole in the wall. It is upstairs. The dim sum is really fresh and good. I was surprised. Portions are decent also, but too bad the service isn't very nice and it takes awhile for the dim sum to come out.
author: Karen H.

description:
Love this place! I found it years ago through a recommendation of a concierge and I come back every time I'm in the Bay Area. 

In the past, I have ordered the pre set meals but this time our group was large ordered off the menu. Our waitress gave amazing recommendations including the honey walnut prawns, hot and sour soup, Peking duck and pot stickers. Everything was amazing.  

I recommend coming with many people so you can try a variety of dishes. They are served family style.
author: Carleigh R.

description:
It was pretty empty here on a Tuesday at 5:30pm, but sure started to fill up about an hour later. Food was pretty good. The hot & sour soup was my favorite. 

The service was nice and quick.
author: Kelly G.

description:
Absolutely fantastic food. The food is a little pricey, but the quality is great. I got the sweet and sour pork, the cashew chicken, the shrimp fried rice, hot and sour soup, and a dim sum combination platter. They were all very delicious, and by far the best I've had. However, the hot and sour soup, while not bad, wasn't the best I've had.
The actual establishment is classy and a great place to take a date, as did I. 
Overall, a great establishment.
author: Colton F.

description: It was really good food. Very family oriented. I went in a Saturday night and it took forever for them to assist us. Also they only took reservations on Saturday night but they let us slide into a small table for 5.
author: Zakary D.

description:
If I could give 0 star... This place is terrible. Bad food... Over priced.... Bad cooking! 
Being Asian, like the other review here, you would wonder why there's no Asian people eating at this place.....
If you know Chinese food, pls do not come here. Most of the people eating are all tourists, ordering simple fired rice and orange chicken.... Their Dimsum menu is way too small... Small serving... Pricey.... And there are no carts.
The waitresses don't speak English... They would not even bother answering you if you have a question. 
Please save yourselves from a bad experience..... 
DO NOT EAT HERE!
author: Zean C.

description: This place has the best Chinese food I've ever eaten! Side note, I'm 35. It was tasty yet light. I've eaten plenty of Chinese food in my time but it's typically very heavy. Not this place. I got the beef with Chinese broccoli and oyster sauce. My date got the seafood rice. Delish!! Five stars!!
author: Jessica F.

description: I like this place. Quiet for a change where you can hear yourself think. Decent and tasty food. Except for when the big tour groups trudge in. Nice to lunch in a pinch.
author: Nancy T.

description: Very clean and very tasty food! The waitress was very nice and gave great recommendations. A bit pricey in proportion to the food quantity, but overall great experience with really good food.
author: Juan R.

description:
Good and tasty food. Waitress very helpful to help me with my selection with dishes for our meal for what we desired.

Very glad for the recommendation by my son.
author: Tammy S.

description: The Shanghai style pork dumplings tempted my vegetarian partner to the dark side for a moment. We both loved them. The mushroom and vermicelli were quite good too. The bbq pork bun was fine but nothing special. Those little pork morsels are so good that this review stays 4 stars despite a disgusting bathroom.
author: Alex M.

description: Exceptional food, exceptional service. Our kids also loved the live crab and lobster tanks. We loved eating here and will be back!
author: Beau W.

description:
Bottom Line:  Good food and a nice dining experience.  Probably the best bet for Chinese food in Chinatown. 

Overall, I liked the Oriental Pearl Restaurant and it would be my go-to choice for Dim Sum in Chinatown.  Having said that, I know the best Dim Sum in San Francisco is not actually in Chinatown.  But if you are in Chinatown and wanting to enjoy some Chinese cuisine this is a good spot to do so.  The restaurant had crisp table clothes, service was attentive and all of the dishes I tried were enjoyable.  The wonton soup, made with fresh, home made wontons was tasty and I really enjoyed the chow fun noodles as well.

When walking through Chinatown you will find that you are solicited by restaurateurs to come and try their these Chinese cuisine. This experience can definitely be overwhelming and annoying. Hopefully Yelp, including this review, will help you narrow down the choices.
author: Courtney K.

description:
Mid afternoon & were browsing then my wife saw it  we walked over went upstairs to check it out! Awards cover the walls the place was packed with lots of locals, always a good sign. 

So we made reservations for 6 that evening. Well 6 came & we walk in, not nearly as busy as lunch, dim sum, does that ya know! So we sit & order, salted pork chops, house chow mein, walnut prawns & for starters a dim sum Appetizer! Summed up everything was fresh, tasty & prepared just right! 

Price wise, very responsible, restaurant is very clean, service was spot on and now I know why it's done so well and has won so many awards!

A 43/4 out of 5 stars
author: Alan B.

description:
The food was horrible at this restaurant!  Sooo disappointed. Sweet and sour pork was cold. What is tha
t??? Vegetable chow mein with pan fried noodles ( also NOT hot or even warm!) had only bok Choy no bean sprouts and very little else. Charged for tea!  Every item was additional. $40 for our order of 2 dishes and a pot of tea!  Awful awful food!  Stay away!!!
author: Suzanne O.

description: No bueno!  You're better off going to Panda Express or some other Chinese restaurant. It's too over price and food wasn't that good.  My girlfriend had the worse veggie dim sum!
author: Nelson B.

description: Out of towner here! This place was very good to our surprise, three appetizers n two main dishes, 3 beers n a soda, for under 90bucks. Food n service great!!
author: Ana A.

description:
The Pearl has lost its luster; been dining here since 1999 and always enjoyed the meal.

Today the entry to the stairwell was dirty and infested with insects buzzing around. Not very enticing.

The dining room is dated, but very clean and comfortable.

The staff was appropropiately attentive.

The Sweet and Sour soup was VERY peppery, but otherwise delicious.

We shared King Pao Chicken and a Salt and Pepper Dungeness Crab. The chicken dish was small and the sauce was excessively reduced. The crab was merely OK --- and it should be great for $46. I felt overeached.

Lots of fond memories of this place; I hope it gets "tuned-up".
author: J S.

description:
Bad service.  Bad service. We were there on a not busy Sunday but seems they try to kick us out as fast as they can. 
Didn't ask for check out. Already took our bill and calculated. Still have food in the plate but come to took all away. This place only for tourist.
author: MK L.

description:
So far my favorite Chinese restaurants in SF. Everything I've tried has been delicious and fresh, including the drinks. I love all of the beef dishes and the sweet and sour pork. 
The service is on point too, and fairly priced, although rice is charged separately but well worth it. Also in a great location in the middle of ChinaTown a short walk up from the financial district.
author: Keagan G.

description:
Ok so let's go straight to the food! Here's what we ordered:

Wonton soup: 3/5, the soup was really bland, but the wontons fillings and texture was quite good.

Steamed dimsum combo: 2/5, the beed shumai was a bit too salty, thought this was overpriced for the portions at $10.

Deep fried sweet and sour cod filet: 4/5, I'm not a deep fried food kind of person so this dish wasn't my cup of tea, but everyone else loved it. I have to say the fish to batter proportion was really good, it wasn't too doughy or too sweet!

Beef with chinese broccoli: 5/5 for the super tender beef and great portion was chinese broccoli. It's stir fried in the typical brown sauce but with a great wok (I'm guessing), the smoky flavor was a great addition, will definitely order again.

Pei pa tofu: 5/5, this was my absolute favorite dish! The tofu was stuffed with minced pork and dried mushrooms in a thick sauce. The tofu texture was perfect, the filling was flavorful and just right. Drooling just thinking about this already!

So besides the two side appetizers the main dishes will have me coming back if I'm in SF again, also the service was very good as well compared to the other restaurants around there!
author: Quynh N.

description:
My friends and I had lunch there today.  Overall, it was a very nice lunch stop.  The pro's were that it was clean and the quality of food was very good.  The only con would be that a few of the dishes (a few of the dim sum items and the won tons in the soup) were over salted.  

I would go there again and maybe stick to the unsalted entrees.
author: Renee M.

description:
Everything started out well....

We had a reservation for 12 and we were promptly seated before anyone waiting in line, which was pretty cool, I have to admit.  But then the fun began.  We sat unattended while the entire restaurant was seated before Rebecca came over to take our drink orders (we had pre-ordered our food because of the size of our party).  So that was 15-20 minutes.  Rebecca was very friendly, outgoing, and came promptly with our drinks.  Then our food started coming out.  Halfway into our first helpings, we were looking for refills but Rebecca was no where to be seen.  Finally, another woman came and started bringing drinks two at a time.  We were celebrating Christmas and were in no hurry, so our meal took more than an hour, however the food came out hot and quick.  Nice.  The food dishes were really very good - the honey walnut shrimp especially - but the Oriental Pearl fried rice tasted like it was 50% green onion and looked it, too.  Not so nice.  We had to ask for steamed rice (I guess because we ordered fried rice, the presumption was that all 12 of us were going to eat it).  We waited a bit for the new waitress to come around for refills again.  Then everything fell apart.  We finished and they started to come and clear our dishes but never brought us a check.  After 15 minutes, I tried signalling to the new waitress who was one table over, but she never looked up.  Another 10 minutes before I finally got her attention and asked for the check.  ANOTHER 15 minutes went by and by this time I felt like jumping on the table to get her attention again.  She came over and I again asked for the check.  She made a face like "Oh, darn, I forgot" and ran off to get it.  When she brought it, we split the check three ways.  We did the math for them, telling the waitress (we wrote it down) which amount went on which credit card.  I swear this is true, another 15 minutes went by.  By this time I got up and went to the cashier/hostess.  I asked if there was a problem with our bill.  The woman said, "Too many credit cards" like their machine was overloaded or something like that made any sense.  So I had to leave to not start yelling.  I waited outside while my party finally got the checks to sign.  I realize in the food industry that splitting the check can be aggravating, but WE DID THE MATH FOR THEM.  All they had to do was run the amounts.

I felt like we went from really important customers to completely unimportant.  This was supposed to be a special event for my family for Christmas and all the joy was sucked out waiting around for someone to see me with my hand raised waving frantically.  Regardless of the quality of the food, I'm never going back.
author: Dave L.

description: Excellent! Great food, good service, nice ambiance. They're helpful -- feel free to ask for recommendations. Definitely recommended!
author: Eric S.

description:
We were recommended this place from one of the shopkeepers around the corner.

Like a lot of places in Chinatown it doesn't look like much from the doorway, but up the stairs it it a real restaurant.

We ordered one of the set dim sum lunches. Served in waves, the items appeared and tasted fresh and well made. I'd only had dim sum from places with a cart. This was quite different. And nice.

Staff was courteous and friendly.

I enjoyed my experience and would return.
author: R H.

description: Came here for dim sum...our usual place is Yank Sing and this place matched in quality and beats them in price...you'll pay 60% and I noticed no difference in variety or quality.  Will come back!
author: Alec G.

description: Awesome restaurant. Fantastic food! Perfect Chinese food for any day! Will definitely be coming back
author: Anna V.

description: So as my adventure started in SF I needed to grab a snack. What better way then to hit up a dim sum place. I'm an early bird so most places aren't open yet. So I got lucky and ran into this place . I walked upstairs to the restaurant and was greeted by this lovely little lady. It was cool being the first to arrive because service was great. I sat next to a window with a cool view of the street so it was perfect for people watching. The lady took my order right away and brought me a drink.  I ended up choosing a few items from the dim sum menu. I told her to let me keep the menu so i can order more if needed. The dim sum was fresh and the prices were reasonable. Good thing I arrived when I did this place filled up fast. I will definitely be back on my next adventure.
author: Tony B.

description:
The best dim-sum ever. Apparently, not all dim-sum places are created equal. Freshly made, taste delicious. We ordered shrimp dumpling and siomay and other standard dimsum meals. We also had thr fried calamari which tasted like none we ate before: soft, fresh, delicious. Also try the mango pudding and freshly made sesame ball. Outside appearance look rundown, but inside is clean and great.
Must try if you are in SF Chinatown!
author: Pete K.

description:
Friday night dinner for two at 6:30. Not crowded. Friendly staff and good service. Vodka martini good. I saw someone warned against hot and sour soup but we split one anyway. Good, not great, and plenty to share. We also got Mongolian beef extra spicy and walnut prawns at server's suggestion. The walnut prawns is something we would normally never order. The prawns were good and sweet candied walnuts gave it an interesting flavor. Mongolian beef good but not great.

Everything was mostly good but not great. With that and the good service I might give 4 stars but considering the cost and the food no better than good carry out, I give it 3.
author: Chuck H.

description: Great service. Recommendations based on everyone's preferences (poultry, vegetarian, spicy, sweet, etc). We ordered four different meals and shared within the group. So yummy! Everything tasted delicious.
author: Isabell F.

description: The inside was beautiful, nice decor, very clean, great service, friendly...but the won ton soup we ordered to share was a very small bowl and $14.50. Price was very high and no flavor. This place seems like more of a touristy place. They did bring us out a complementary egg custard tart to try and that was very yummy.
author: Natalie K.

description: This place is awesome! The price is right for awesome dim sum, delicious food, and nice atmosphere for dinner. Would 10/10 recommend to friends for a nice dinner in Chinatown!
author: Mackenzie W.

description: Authentic Hong Kong style dishes and westernized Chinese food sum up the menu. I like both styles and appreciate the chance to east sea cucumbers, abalone, hot pots and other Hong Kong classics. The restaurant is cheesy, the service is dry, but the food is very good. Prices are very fair. A worthwhile stop for anybody who likes Chinese food.
author: Jim M.

description: More a tourist place with lots of awards on the wall. Can't figure where these came from. Food was lower average. We had menu A. Pricey. Good service though. Clean. Not very crowded. 3 other parties. All were non Asian.
author: Drgxd K.

description: It was.... ok. The service was ok. The food was ok. It was just ok. This place is ULTRA touristy, you won't find a single Asian diner anywhere, and that's usually a sign. There are much better places in town for much less. I rarely use this term but it's pretty much a tourist trap.
author: Shane W.

description:
Not sure why this restaurant has less than five stars.  Every dish we had was amazing and the ice tea was some of the best I've ever had. We actually went and bought some of the loose leaf tea from a store a few doors down. 

For food, we had shrimp fried rice, steamed pork buns, fresh stir fried vegetables, shrimp and chive dumplings and sweet and sour chicken.  

We came on a Sunday and the service was very good. 

The restaurant is also very clean and much nicer than many of the other options in China town.
author: Chris C.

description:
This year was my turn to plan the lunch stop in Chinatown when myself and 5 friends wanted dinner - with so many places to try, how do you choose?  Yelp reviews were the answer and the correct answer!

On Clay Street, it was pretty easy to find, doesn't look like much from the outside, but once up the stairs, it's a wonderful looking restaurant, very clean, very understated and very quiet as it's one floor off the street.  Yes, we were a little put off that we were the only persons in the restaurant when we started, but by the end of our lunch, we were the only non-Asians in the place!  That means a lot.

We ordered the Dim Sum lunch for 4 persons, additional non-shrimp portions for our seafood allergic friend, and a vegetarian lunch for the vegan among us.  Very beautiful presentations of the food, the hostess (she could have been the owner, I didn't ask) took the time (along with our server) to explain what the different items were, what sauces to eat them with, etc.

Great place to rest for a few minutes and regroup before hitting the tourist spots in the afternoon.

Probably a 4.5 out of 5 stars in my book.
author: Liz T.

description: Very nice decor and ambiance. The staff were very welcoming and made great recommendations. The food was amazing! If you want a delicious, authentic dinner in Chinatown, this is the place to go!
author: Michelle R.

description: Food was oily, overpriced, and small portioned. Service was attentive and bathroom was clean. I wouldn't be back.
author: Alex I.

description: We had chicken chow main,vegetables fried rice,Mongolian beef and general t-sao chicken and everything was excellent!!
author: Rocio A.

description: Our meal came with 2 spoons that were dirty. Ordered 2 dishes, 1 appetizer and 4 white rice... we paid $60. I think this is a bit pricey. I will not be a returning customer.
author: Joy A.

description:
I had not had Chinese food this good in a very long time. I ordered the chicken in black bean sauce lunch special which came with a bowl of some delicious corn soup. I also ordered some dim sum, the lobster/chive dumpling and the vegetable dumpling; both good but I liked the lobster/chives one better. The service was excellent, everyone was polite. It is on the pricey side but it's well worth it because the food here is delicious af. I agree with previous reviewers who mentioned that the cook of this place is insanely gifted. Would definitely come and eat here again. 

TL; DR ?: it's delicious ! Pricey but worth it.
author: Stars S.

description: This is the cleanest Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Oriental Pearl specializes in Dim Sum and serves dishes to order. No Dim Sum carts here. All of their dim sum is fresh. It may be a bit overpriced for a typical, noisy dirty dim sum restaurant but that's a trade off if you want to eat in a serene, clean and calm environment. It's across the street to the underground parking so it's nice and convenient.
author: Calvin N.

description: This place has mystery meat and chicken at tourist prices.  It's not a high quality food restaurant and the prices are double any regular Asian restaurant.  I would pass on this place if you are considering.  The only this good was pre made fortune cookies and the service.
author: Eric D.

description: The service is absolutely great! We came here with a party of 8.  The waitress gave us great suggestions and not one of them disappointed! We had jasmine tea, Chinese broccoli with oyster sauce, Mongolian beef, pecking duck, and much much more! One of our go-to restaurants when we come to San Francisco
author: Bryant E.

description: Great Chinese food, good prices and quick service. It's Linen table clothes and napkins, nice place to for sit down dinner or lunch.
author: David M.

description: Delicious!! Such amazing food! I am not normally a fan of fried rice, but their fried rice is amazing! I also tried their sweet and sour pork, pork buns, chicken chow mein, egg rolls and dim sum. It was so delicious, we came back to chinatown the second day as well! It is a little bit pricy, but completely worth it!
author: Noelle P.

description: This was recommended but was awful & ridiculously priced. Wonton soup for 2 $16. Awful
author: Liz R.

description: I came here on recommendations from locals after wanting a dim sum place in Chinatown that wasn't too big or difficult to get into. Oriental Pearl definitely fits that bill - it's a small restaurant that has two entrances, one of which is nonfunctioning, and you have to go up a less indirect door to the left of the restaurant in order to get in. Once inside, you might notice pretty quickly that the décor isn't all that special - but what really sold me on the place, as it will probably you, is the food. It's great for the price. Typical dim sum fare, made to order, was served quickly and was piping hot - not least it was delicious. The wait staff is extremely genial and feels like you're sitting down to eat with a family - the owner stopped me during my order and told me "You're ordering too much food for one person!" She meant it kindly, and it only served to make you feel like they really wanted you to have the most comfortable experience possible there. I loved this place and would absolutely recommend it to anyone who asks for weekday dim sum.
author: Jay C.

description: SF Native who rarely ventures into Chinatown for dinner. Having read other reviews we gave it a go. We had a reservation, so were seated right away. It took ten minutes for any staff to come to our table to offer even water or menus. Service continued to be slow to non-existent.  Won Ton and Hot and Sour soups were served lukewarm, sweet and sour chicken was likewise room temperature.  Staff vacuuming the restaurant during dinner made it hard to have a conversation. With so many awesome Asian food options in SF I cannot see any reason to return.
author: Erin N.

description: My husband and I ate at the Oriental Pearl last Friday night while visiting San Francisco.  When we arrived,  there were two other tables with people seated. A couple at one and three adults at the other.  We were seated promptly and our order was taken by the lady who seated us.  Other people continued to arrive and be seated. After 20 or more minutes we noticed that those who came in after us had their food. We had ordered an appetizer and two entrees.  Other waiters and waitresses were attending to other tables but our waitress never came back to us even though she was seating everyone and taking their orders.  After 50 minutes we stopped another waitress and asked if she could find out where our food was.  We then stopped the original lady who took our order and seated us and she made some excuse about ours taking longer because of the appetizer--Even though everybody around us had already gotten their appetizers and entrees and finished eating. Finally, one hour after we arrived the waitress brought our entree and said they were working on our appetizer.  They offered a free dessert for the inconvenience.   We cancelled the appetizer and the dessert was not worth eating.  The waitress/hostess was clearly managing the rest of the staff and just forgot us.  Poor management. She should at least have acknowledged her mistake instead of making up an excuse and blaming it on our appetizer order.   This is the first time I have ever left a restaurant review. Very disappointed in the Oriental Pearl.
author: Shelia C.

description: Was a bit nervous walking upstairs to this restaurant but was very happy we did. We had pot stickers, Mongolian Beek, and General Tsaos Chicken. All were fantastic. The staff was very professional, bathrooms are clean, and atmosphere was nice.
author: Matt E.

description:
Joe is the nicest hardest working man in Chinatown . This restaurant is fantastic!! I'm truly addicted to the Mai Tai's here! The salted lobster melts in your mouth. The Kung pao perfection and an all time fave honey walnut shrimp. I also love the hot and sour soup. Clean table cloths excellent service and a smoothly run operation . Stephen was also wonderful !!
Thank you thank you!!
author: Cecilia D.

description: Very good food, and very affordable. Had the shell prawns with spicy salt, soup dumplings, eggplant stuffed with shrimp, and ftied taro dumpling with pork and mushrooms. All was good as it was dim sum from a menu and came out piping. Hot the shrimp could have been a touch crispier, but the scallions and pepper topping was spot on. Best fried taro dumpling I have ever had.
author: Andrew B.

description: Eggplant in clay pot is delicious. Staples shrimp fried rice and chicken chow mein were disgusting and bland. Reviews looked good but should have turned around when it seemed there were no locals, just harried tourists like ourselves. Go elsewhere.
author: Megan M.

description:
Dim sum options in San Francisco's Chinatown are in vast abundance. As you walk through the little neighborhood, restaurant workers stand outside the doors and aggressively beckon you to come inside. Don't give into their pressure and conniving pleas; rather, thoughtfully consult your Yelp app for recommendations. That's exactly what we did to find Oriental Pearl. 

We sauntered in on a lazy, late Sunday morning and were seated without a problem. The dim sum menu was quite extensive. Between four of us, we ordered a lot. Some of the items that stood out to me:

BBQ PORK BUN:  Nicely executed. This is one of those addicting options that one can just keep noshing on over and over again. 

SHRIMP & CHIVES DUMPLING:  I ordered this twice. I just couldn't get enough of it.

VEGETABLE EGG ROLLS:  Piping hot. Very satisfying.

BBQ SPARE RIBS:  A nice snack that I shared with another person at the table. They weren't overly sauced, something that I appreciated. Light and tangy.

Servers were very sweet and kind. A team of them attentively took care of us throughout our stay. They made sure the food kept coming and coming. I applaud them for keeping up since we ordered an abundance of items. 

Each item ranged from $3.50 - $4.75. Certainly commensurate with other dim sum options in the area. 

I wouldn't mind returning to Oriental Pearl again. I very much enjoyed my visit.
author: Gary R.

description:
Rip off, go elsewhere. Ordered the dim sum sampler for $10. Received 6 crummy shu mai. Spicy braised chicken was good, but $18 was outrageous considering all the other options in Chinatown with quality cuisine.

Annoyed me enough to write my first review on Yelp.
author: Charles F.

description: Ordered the wonton soup and it was horrible. Rancid taste made it non-edible. The honey walnut shrimp was a little better, but had a sour aftertaste. Good service, just terrible food.
author: Brian B.

description: This place is an absolutely  wonderful restaurant. The food here is very fresh and the Spices and flavor very spot on. The Service here is extremely friendly & very fast. They have always made our experience amazing consistently going above and beyond to make every occasion special.
author: Bobby B.

description: Food wasn't good. Service was spotty. A little pricey. The water glasses were TINY. We travel all over, and we had high hopes... save your money!
author: Alex D.

description: Shrimp with honey walnut is great. Fried rice was also good and very fresh. Food wasn't covered up with a bunch of overpowering sauce.
author: Michele N.

description: We didn't have good experience in here. More than 15% gratuity was automatically applied to our receipt. Without any notice, the bottom line asks us to pay tips again. Very dishonest. In other words, they were asking us to pay double tips, and the gratuity amount is not even optional. Please try to avoid dining in this restaurant.  NOT Recommended!
author: Wendy D.

description: When in San Francisco, a must have! Their food was outstanding, their service was on the spot, and their prices very reasonable! Start with the Salt & Pepper Calamari and Dim Sum Combination (BEST I'VE EVER HAD!) Nothing like it! Hell, order two of them! Their Fried Rice, Mongolian Beef, and Kung Pao Shrimp were phenomenal!
author: Rene B.

description:
I went here with my boss and my colleague while we were in town for a conference. While the steep hills of SanFran did have me winded, Oriental Pearl is worth the trek.
I was kind of surprised to find it almost empty... it had been noted in my boss' guidebook that it was a really popular spot! But I guess it worked out, as we received attentive service, as they consistently checked up on us and explained menu items.

The chow fun was a little different from what I had expected, as it used long noodles instead of the flat square ones I am accustomed to. Nonetheless, delicious! Great soy sauce flavor with greens. Typical fare.
For our main entree, we got the live crab. Flavored with salt and pepper, it was DELICIOUS. We happily donned our aprons and gloves and clawed through every bite, I definitely recommend. Simple and delicious!
author: Rumi F.

description:
Love this place! We stop by every time we're in the City and sometimes twice if we're there for a few days.
It's a bit pricey but very yummy and service is good. Seems like it's popular with tourists as well.
author: Monica H.

description:
Good service , good food 
It's little bit over over priced for this quality
The fried meet rice was very good 
Duck wrap was delicious
author: Raymond H.

description:
If I could give this place a zero stars- I would!! Waited a very long time after watching many others get seated ahead of us- then we were ushered to a table where we were ignored by EVERYONE 
No eye contact - nothing!! We tried to wave over a waitress several times- after almost 25 minutes of not even receiving a glass of water or a menu!
We finally got up to leave and told the hostess who seemed unfazed and unapologetic.  Never again
author: Dagmar S.

description:
Great fancy place to eat Dim Sum. We ordered the A. 

Bottom line is the food was great. All of it had a home cooked taste. 

I would recommend eating here if in the Chinatown area.
author: Mark P.

description: Got there close to closing for lunch. They were very courteous and did not rush us. Food was good and fresh. Dim sum was good
author: Carol K.

description:
Overall good dining experience. Food was fresh and delicious (although, not the best I've ever had). Wait staff was very attentive, and checked up on us many times.

We ordered a few dishes off the main menu, but mostly stuck to dim sum. We arrived at around 1:40 pm and the restaurant was not packed. Only two other large tables. One of the cleaner restaurants in the Chinatown area.

All in all, a very solid restautant. Not the best, but far from the worst. I would definitely recommend it as a good dining experience if you happen to be in the area, but probably would not travel out of my way to get here.
author: Andy C.

description: I'm here for a conference for work.  During the planning stages, two people had mentioned this place separately.  From my understanding, San Fransisco has some of the best and most authentic cuisine in China Town that you can get in the States.  This place, while fantastic and worth the 5 stars, wouldn't be authentic I think.  But it was damn good and glad I went. We had to be difficult and ask for separate itemized checks for reimbursement purposes.  They didn't care, so that was nice.  We got Hot and Sour soup to start.  It had a good spice to it, and it was portioned enough for a meal for 1 or shared for 3.  My colleague got the General Tso's chicken.  It was good, but not spicy.  I have thing for a little spice on my life.  My other colleague went with the Mongolian Beef and special rice.  It was delicious.  The veggies were cooked just right and the beef was good in quality and quantity.  I went with the Peking Duck w/pancakes.  The portion was enough for the three of to share.  Cooked just right.  Delicious.  And we had hot tea with the meal.  Great wait staff, great food.  I recommend it :). See the pictures to sate your visual appetite...
author: Jason D.

description: I usually skeptical with anything in Chinatown, mostly tourist trap restaurants....  I do however have to say that the food is good here, had beef with scallion, beef chow fun, and pippa tofu.  There is things in the menu definitely for tourist, like "general too chicken", Etc. but I have to say the cook really knows how to cook, Chinese food.  The thing is, the price is kind of high for regular Chinese food.  The service also pretty good, they are very attentive to customer....  the rating deserve a little higher than the 3.5 star average....  May not be the "up to date" Cantonese seafood you'll get at some of the banquet seafood restaurant, but it was very well made food....
author: Steve D.

description: Excellent! Excellent service, excellent food and excellent ambience. Perfect for conversation. As you see, I really enjoyed this dining experience. The food was delivered quick and hot. This restaurant is on my San Fran best list.
author: Kim T.

description: The Oriental Pearl held so much promise for us but sigh, I don't think one person in our party enjoyed their meal and we all left a little unsatisfied. Not a lot of flavor, lots of oil. Maybe it would be better for a dim sum lunch rather than dinner.
author: Karen A.

description:
I have lived in the area for a while and typically frequent the same favored places for dim sum. Friends thought it was time to try someplace new (to us).

Upscale (tablecloth) place for dim sum. More limited menu that some other places but most of the dishes we ordered were very very good:

My fave was the sticky rice in lotus leaves. A friend's was the fried turnip cake. Pork buns only available steamed, not baked. Shanghai dumplings not that impressive. Chef was busy for CNY so didn't have time to make egg custards. 

Overall great meal and will definitely be back. Place was empty when they opened and am almost a little reluctant to give a good review because I don't want this place to start getting crowded for future visits. 

They validate parking for meals at least $50. Don't think they validate more than one car for $50 meal if you come in a group, depending on which waiter you get. 

Entrance is up the block from actual address, restaurant on 2nd floor...take the stairs up one flight.
author: D L.

description:
As I made the right onto Clay off of Grant things started to feel familiar I entered Oriental Pearl, climbed up the stairs made another right into the entrance and realized I had been here back in 1998, was my 1st time.

Caroline the current owner [daughter of the original owners] seated me in front of the fish tanks, said to her I had been here b/4 back in 1998 sat on the other side. Mentioned the place looked a little different Caroline stated she had painted actually it was the same color grey but w/a hue of purple vs. the mauve her Mother used to have. Was nice to see things where still the same but freshened up.

Started off with a beer, Caroline stopped by to check on me mentioned I was baffled on what to order she suggested the Combo of Steamed Dim Sum 
[Pork, Beef, Pork and Shrimp] the Beef was my FAV then the Chicken and I ordered the Peking Duck Served with Pancakes...1st time I've ever had.

Since I wasn't having a Thanksgiving Dinner thought why not try the duck...it was incredible. The waitress rolled each one for me each w/a little Plum Sauce not too much.

I was so full there was no room for dessert Caroline was kind enough to bring over a glass filled with chilled Lychee's for me...was a nice little Birthday treat.

The best & cute part was the Rooster carved out of Carrot that was served w/the Peking Duck actually placed him across from me so I had a dinner companion.

Thank you Caroline and your family for keeping all the recipes true and amazing my next trip back I will be there again!
author: Flyinlow ..

description: Unremarkable food (even the peking duck, which was tasty, but cold and not crispy). Much better Chinese options in city.
author: Sarah T.

description: Good service and great food in the heart of San Francisco's Chinatown. You won't be dissatisfied, ordered the almond chicken, chicken chow-mien and sweet and sour pork all done nicely with enough food for every one on the table. Will come back for sure.
author: Karyn D.

description:
Just had secret steam egg dish for the second time!!!
It is not on the menu, but tastes excellent.  
My wife who is very picky about food, was really happy!
author: Yuichi A.

description: My husband and I eat at Oriental Pearl monthly, either at the restaurant or we order and pick up enough for 2 nights.  It's not good, it's GREAT!!  We're always warmly welcomed by Rebecca with hugs. Last night we had Won Ton soup, hot and sour soup, spicy shell prawns, beef & scallions and a noodle dish, as well as half an order of Peking duck.  Tonight we finished it off. The entire staff is excellent!!
author: anne l.

description:
Visiting from out of town and had some friends that came out to San Fran a couple months ago that told us to try this place. So glad we did. Atmosphere is very clean and neat. The lunch menu can keep you under $10 a plate, but the food can get very expensive (chef choice start at  $25 and go up to $55). The service is spot on, but more professional than laid back. The entire staff stays very dedicated to making sure tables are cleaned as soon as they get up, waters are full, and customers are satisfied!  The food is fantastic, I wish I could go into detail, but there isn't much to tell. It is just spot on Chinese.  This place is a must stop in Chinatown.

There is a local parking deck on the corner of Clay St and Kearny St underneath the park, and it's one of the reasonably priced ones in town ($27 for a full day). But that's about it for parking, street is usually full.
author: Tony B.

description: As a foodie, I'm quite surprised this gets strong reviews from Zabars, Michelin, et all.  The food was OK at best.   It was definitely overpriced, portions were small, and service was slow.  They even delivered the 3 main dishes for 3 of us at totally different times.
author: Sarah E.

description: Over priced chinese restaurant..  we had the peking duck.. the crepe was so thick.. they've included the meat when it should only be the skin.. the skin wasn't crispy.. had their steamed fish.. it was ok.. and the oriental fried rice was bland.. overall we paid almost $100.. wrong move.. we could've gone to the restaurant next door and had way better meal for cheap.. our server that day was nice though...
author: Laura M.

description:
Oriental Pearl was recommended by a merchant in Chinatown. She was right! 

The dim sum was delicious and not as expensive as other highly rated venues. The items are made to order. Ingredients were fresh and served hot. Fried items were not greasy. My favorite is the fried taro puff. It was really good. We also enjoyed the house special chicken meatball wrapped in egg white. There is only one to an order. The standards are 3 to an order. No mai gai (steamed sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf) serving is 2 pieces.

The restaurant is very clean.  The room could be refreshed a tad. The staff actually cleans the glass lazy susans with windex AND a clean cloth. Service by all was so polite and efficient. They accepted a reservation for 2!

Definitely high on my short list of places to go for dim sum in San Francisco. This is one place where you would be wrong to assume the dim sum was bad because there weren't many Chinese dining there.  Let's just say the tourists got a good meal!
author: Debbie T.

description:
Food was average. We had general t'sos, hot and sour soup and King Pao chicken.
Service not flexible on allowing to adjust any additions or subtraction to the desired dish.
Glad we tried it but would not go back.
author: John P.

description: Ate here on a Friday night for a casual business dinner. Nothing fancy, average at best. The décor is dated. Nothing was horrible but nothing stood out. Had comparable food at the mall for half the price. The servers were polite and the fast.
author: Erin K.

description:
Must have been an off day when I visited this restaurant on a Monday evening. Dropped by restaurant while on a conference in San Francisco. First, the restaurant decor is nothing to write home about, though you would not expect much from a Chinatown restaurant.

Ordered Peking duck, Mongolian beef and ginger scallion dungeness crab. While the ornament accompanying the duck was fancy, the duck was not hot and the skin was soggy, as opposed to the crisp expected from Peking duck. The crab meat such to the inside of the shell and was a little dry, although the seasoning was OK. The only redeeming dish was the beef, which was tender and nicely seasoned. Yet, for the price tag, I was underwhelmed. Better places to check out in Chinatown.
author: Li Q.

description:
Being in San Fran and having Chinatown nearby, we were looking for Peking Duck and our hotel recommended Oriental Pearl. 
While the duck was fine .. the pancakes were terrible .. doughy and tasted nothing like you are use to ... and for reasons they couldn't explain they served the duck with carrots instead of scallions and cucumbers. When I asked for scallions and cukes... they said no. 

Dim Sums were just ok ...The soup was good as was the house fried rice.  

The restaurant is upstairs and very clean, not what you expected when you walked in. 

Overall ... A real disappointment
author: Michael C.

description: We went here with a group of 28.  Tour leader ordered ahead so there was no wait time. Service was quick   Only problem only 1 ladies room. Food was certainly acceptable-- but I'm not really qualified to critique this cuisine. Enjoyed all but the dumpling, but remember I'm so expect. We had the dim sum served family style.
author: Lynda C.

description: Oriental Pearl has great service, nice decor, but very overpriced food. We tried their peking duck and stir-fried pea sprouts. The duck was over $50 for maybe half a pound of meat, and it wasn't even that good. The meat was tasty, but the skin was soggy and chewy :( The pea sprouts a bit stringy and nothing special--definitely not worth the $20 they cost. On top of all that, they charge $3 per pot of tea.
author: Maddie D.

description: I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this place.  It totally caters to tourists who are drawn here by its reputation.  The food isn't cheap, but the staff clearly cares about making a good dining experience which I can't say for many of the restaurants in Chinatown.  Although their focus is Cantonese style, they did an admirable job with the Peking duck.
author: Seth E.

description: We had heard about the R&G Lounge, but were turned off by the bad cleanliness report and decided to come here instead. Great choice, great service. It was very clean and everyone was friendly! The food was great and it was very kid friendly.
author: Abbey N.

description:
12/29/16 11:15am
Got off the Big Bus Hop On/Off Bus at the Chinatown gates.  We were hungry looking for a place to eat that had high Yelp reviews.  Each restaurant we saw I checked the Yelp rating and cleanliness factor.  This restaurant had good reviews and had high cleanliness.

We weren't disappointed!  We got there right before the lunch rush.  The decor was pleasant.  The entrance was a little confusing.  The bathroom was clean and stocked.  We ordered  from the lunch special menu.  Kung Pao Chicken and Mongolian Beef.  It was tasty and hit the spot.  The egg flower soup was excellent and perhaps the best I've ever had.  We even enjoyed the tea very much.  The bill was very reasonably priced for the good food, good service and clean dining area and rest room.

This was the best Chinese restaurant we dined at out of the three we sampled.  We would come here again.  I recommend this place!
author: Geo P.

description:
Dim sums were delicious and the wait staff was nice in accommodating us close to their afternoon closing time. It's because of that, I am giving a star extra. The other main dish was strictly ordinary.
Chicken with black bean sauce didn't do much for the palate. 
Go for dim sums, appetizer platter and nice ambience. Not so much for the main course!
author: Monu M.

description: Food was great, but we wanted more Pork Buns and they kept saying "Oh, no more Pork Buns for you!" We felt like it was an episode of Seinfeld, "No Soup for You." My son is 6'2 and went home hungry. They kept taking our plates and sauces away from us when we still wanted to order more food, which the last time I checked is why restaurants are there. It wasn't even close to closing time of 9:30, it was only 7:30-8:00 and the restaurant was still half full. Don't you want our money???
author: Craig R.

description: This review is for fish maw soup. The best. Also ask for chicken meat balls. This time they were out.
author: Mete C.

description:
What is authentic Chinese food?
Like any cuisine, the answer is defined by its audience.  While someone from the Midwest or Southern states might mention places like Panda Express and P.F. Chang, SoCal (Monterey Park and Rowland Heights mainly) residents, like in Monty Python's Holy Grail, might answer with another questions, "What kind?"... leading to a plethora of Northern style, Southern style, Hong Kong or Taiwan vs. Mainland styles, or lead into another question... "What region?"
This leads me to this quiet, hidden restaurant in the heart of the touristy part of Chinatown off of Grant Avenue.  
My mother was born in Shantou, center of Chiu Chow (also spelled Teo Cheow)people where, not only is the food different, the language and, in many ways, mentality is different.  When the Japanese occupied China during WWII, many locals from this region fled to Viet Nam and Singapore.  This is why many Vietnamese immigrants in the Bay Area likely speak Chiu Chow dialect.
Back in the 1980's, there were two Chiu Chow restaurants, the upstairs restaurant now named Clay Pot City and a small place on 9th Avenue near Judah, now .
Being my mom's birthday, I wanted to do something special to celebrate and remembered that the owners are from there and offer some staple dishes.  

Appetizers
1) Shrimp Balls (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=KLW-gN80RdqdAKqIKSowhg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - I know... so many jokes can be made on this one.  Pretty good as the filling had the authentic flavor though the skin seemed a bit thick.  A bit pricey at $9.25 for four balls.

2) Marinade Duck Chiu Chow style  (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=hSAu823ye17ZSyp4v2eWYw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - This homestyle prepared dish is made in the traditional manner and served with a white vinegar garlic dipping sauce.  Being heavily flavored, goes well with rice. 

Soup
3) Minced Beef Soup with Egg White  (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=_zlS9KApRoRBbroGUvJe9w&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Never seen a restaurant apportion takeout soup in five individual small containers like this.  Would have be tastier with cilantro.

Mains
4) Spicy Braised Chicken  - Even the owner warned me that this was not cooked in authentic Chiu Chow style with basil leaves.  This is a Chiu Chow cuisine signature dish that didn't quite hit the mark.

5) Braised Rock Cod Fish Filet with Minced Pork, Shrimp, and Tofu Clay Pot (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=pWQA4SfaquyoD5L69THPLQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -Recommended by the owner, this was just 'meh'.  No distinct flavor though cooked with peeled garlic cloves.  Pass.

6) Olive Leaf Green Bean stir fry (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=9m9A02tRBCaDRbSfSNP3lg&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Another Chiu Chow dish, it was on the saltier side (too much olive leaves?) and would have benefited if cooked with ground pork for more flavoring.

Dessert
7)  Taro pudding (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=K-mHhn5LWl7gI2_5zLYCqQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Probably the best dish of the evening.  Usually served family style, like the soup, apportioned in five small takeout containers.  Imagine your mom or grandmother mashing taro to a poi-like consistency, but with sweet flavors.  The gingko nuts confirmed the dish's authenticity.  A single serving is $5.75.

Sadly, my mom cannot fault me for the effort, but, if she knew what I paid for dinner, my ears would probably be chewed off.  All main dishes were $10.00 + with the fish being the tops at $16.75.
I don't profess to be an expert in Chiu Chow cooking like my mom, but she's educated my palate to certain expectations.  From my first trip to Hong Kong when she told me about a small place upstairs in the herb district in Sheung Wan to the local places that opened in the late 1980's in Chinatown and in the Sunset District, she would order their staple dishes that bring back memories of her childhood.  In the late '80's to late '90's, my work travels took me to Hong Kong annually where my cousins would take me to a Chiu Chow restaurant near the Macau ferry.  Now, if only there was enough of an audience to warrant bringing those chefs here.  Sadly, a magazine cover with Rachel Ray about under $40.00 per day adorns their entrance window (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q), evidence of the audience that they target.
author: Mike C.

description: We stopped in for a late lunch, having seen the sign on the street. After walking up the staircase, we were pleasantly surprised at the decor. Several aquariums displayed beautiful fish, and the tables were graced with live orchids. It was not crowded, and we got a table right next to the window. We thoroughly enjoyed the corn chowder and sea food fried rice we shared.
author: Susan M.

description:
Very mediocre. High prices, overly salty food. They charge $2 for a small bowl of rive, $19.25 for my favorite vegetable dish with no meat (pea pods with garlic sauce). Very disappointing. It was edible, but there are so many better places to go in Chinatown for significantly less money.

The white table cloth and linen napkins certainly appeal to a particular nonAsian crowd, and we should have realized we needed  leave when the only Asians we saw were working there.
author: Mrs. S.

description:
This is a hidden gem! Amazing food - very tasty, authentic, friendly staff. I usually have the dim sum for 2 and it's always plenty. The pork buns are divine! Chow mein very good also. 

Will be going back time and time again - very highly recommended and very reasonably priced.
author: Laura T.

description:
I wasn't sure about the place by the entrance, but after walking upstairs (there is an elevator) was pleasantly surprised. They have a commitment to quality and it shows! 

The house special dim sun was fantastic, with an incredibly light  wrapper on the shrimp and such fantastic flavor! The Barbecue spare ribs were meaty and moist, and very flavorful. The house dried rice was delectable, and the signature dish of fresh lo an prawns with sweet walnuts me yes in my mouth!  

Go... Enjoy! 

Pricing was also very good, but not cheap.
author: Foodie I.

description: Food was excellent. We were looking for a clean, yummy restaurant in Chinatown and this was recommended. Service was a little slow but the quality of the food made up for it.
author: Katy P.

description:
Horrible service... Horrible food..Horrible decor..Oh, and Rachael Ray likes this place? 

I tested this place out when I was visiting SF and I am honestly not impressed. First of all, this place was completely empty during lunch time on a weekend, and it is obvious it is going downhill. My little sister and I ordered the Chef's Suggestion Meal for Two (Order B)  with Tofu Soup, house special dim sum, prawns with honey glazed walnut, Kung Pao chicken, and oriental pearl rice. Those are generic items that I assumed would be hard to mess up. Before I explain how nasty the food is, it took me about SIX TIMES where I had to ask for water before getting some to my table. The service sucked and we were never checked up on. 

The dim sum tasted like it was something frozen that had been heated up. The tofu soup was basically really bad egg drop soup with bits of tofu in it. The prawns disappointed us the most. I usually love honey walnut shrimp and this tasted like there was pineapple juice squeezed onto it along with mayo lathered over fried prawns. the Kung Pao chicken was very bare. I couldn't tell between the water chestnuts and the diced up chicken because turned out there was twice as much chestnuts compared to chicken... 

Overall, I did not enjoy my experience here at all despite all the accolades and awards it has received. I would not recommend this place.
author: Thao P.

description:
Had a good mix of different dishes . Very good some of the best chicken chow mien noodles I have had . Each dish was delicious. I enjoyed the Mongolian beef when normally I don't even like it.
4 stars good food!!
author: Ryan B.

description:
This place was a hard mediocre. The menu looked pretty bland, but they had a cheap lunch special, so we went in. Food turned out to be as bland as the menu, but seemed to be fresh, and was not bad. There was an entire tour group of about 30 (!) people there, to give you an idea of the clientele. 

Service was fine. The bathroom smelled like somebody had poured concentrated cleaning solutions all over the floor and left it to evaporate. Really, really gross at a restaurant. (But at least you know it's clean?) Actually, the restaurant really deserves three stars, but the chemical bathroom smell was so offensive, I am taking it down to two stars. 

From the reviews, it sounds like dim sum is the way to go. Too bad my experience here was so different from everyone else's. :-\
author: Kelly R.

description:
Came in here on a Saturday for lunch with a small group. My daughter wanted fried rice with egg and sesame balls. I ordered off the dim sum menu. Told them that I wanted Chinese broccoli and otherwise gave them my eating restrictions and told her to pick for me. I'm glad it did. She brought me shrimp balls and vegetable dumplings. Delicious. 

My daughter's sesame balls looked wonderful but she loved them so much I couldn't even get a taste. 

At one point during the meal, my daughter spilled her water all over me. The staff was quick to respond and very accomodating showing their excellent customer service. 

With a health rating in the 90s where others seemed to be in the 70s, I would say Oriental Pearl is a winner.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Made a return visit. Had dim sum and Mongolian Beef. High expectations from the last time. This time was disappointing. Food  flavors were good, but service was not. Everything came out at the same time. By the time I finished the dim sum the entree was cold. Didn't see a server again until he brought the check.
author: Jim R.

description: Super yum! Shrimp and veggies. Mushrooms and shrimp were very fresh and hands down the best looking eggdrop soup. Very good dim sum, we plan to return very soon!
author: Justin T.

description:
The sign on the outside is not representative of how nice it looks on the inside. Came on a weekday and wasn't disappointed

Some people mentioned other places being dirty. If that's a problem try here!
author: Eric L.

description: Dimsum comes in smaller portions than most  places. A little pricey too, but other than that the service was great and the food wasn't bad either. Definitely a tourist type of spot.
author: Joanne G.

description: Delicious! So glad we stopped here! Only had about a 15 minute wait on a Saturday night. Everyone was so nice and they bring out the food and assemble it in front of you. Helpings are plenty! We ordered Dim Sum, half a Peking Duck, and Chicken Fries Rice for 2 of us to share. We were sooo full and couldn't finish the rice. The duck was AMAZING!!
author: Tabitha H.

description: We shared 3 dishes: fried rice, beef and noodle. All were very well prepared and the beef was one of the most tender I have had in a Chinese restaurant. I certainly would go back
author: Louis M.

description: No complaints!! I'm very picky so that's a big deal for me. The egg rolls were so yummy and the sweet shrimp (I'm not sure what exactly it was but it was shrimp in a sweet sauce) was soooo good. Came here for a work lunch. Def a good pick. More family style  than dim sum style.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Amazing food and taste. The dumplings are beyond explanation. Orgasm of flavor in your mouth. Pork dumpling shanghai style is worth the mention. Pork buns just melted in your mouth. 

Every dish that we ordered was better than the last one. The tea was complementing the food too. 

Can't think of anything bad.
author: Abhinandan D.

description: This was recommended by a local shop owner.  We were quite pleased.  Reasonably priced Dim Sum. Service was great.  Upscale environment.
author: Greg M.

description: Went with a large group.  Food was absolutely mediocre.  Not one of the dozen or so dishes we ordered stood out as anything more than over-oiled, under-cooked takeout fare.  On top of it, service was awfully slow--took over an hour to get steamed rice and we never actually got full serving utensils and water glasses for the whole party. No idea what everyone else experienced here.
author: Randy S.

description:
Here is the worst restaurant I have ever been.
We were looking for some restaurants to have a lunch but there were no restaurants opening on Christmas so we went to a Chinese restaurant; One of my worst memory was coming from this point. A waitress came to us and asked whether we want a glass of water or hot tea. We answered water and hot tea and naturally we thought both of them would be free. And guess what. Although we didn't know it would be charged, we had to pay for "that tea bag hot water." It is not all. I gotta say about the Food(noodles and beef satay). Those are ridiculously pricey and quality and service is like whatever. It was like junk food taste. And you know, Chinatown in S.F is usually crowded with visitors, so it was like they do never care about customers.
Until now, I've never commented before in Yelp. But this restaurant gave me one of the worst memory, I feel like must prevent other sacrifices who would decide to go there from a nightmare.
I sure will never ever recommend this worst restaurant.
author: Hyojeong A.

description: What the hell, this is the best dim sum that I ever had!! Tasted like every spice, salt, and food were perfectly made in right portions just for me. Coming again and recommending it to all family and friends. Fun fact: they make their own rice noodle rolls. so fresh~
author: Hina W.

description: Excellent Dim Sim restaurant in Chinatown, San Francisco. The 3 of us had a selection of Dim Sim (7 in all) for less than $40/-. The dishes were delicate and tasted excellent. Very authentic and in my opinion very well priced. The restaurant is on the first floor and is neat and tidy, not like some of the other restaurants.
author: Meng L.

description: Very clean dimsum place.  The menu describes clearly the vegetarian and the non-vegetarian items. Very attentive staff. We had jasmine tea with our dimsum. Dimsum can be ordered till after 2:30 PM which is great as we were running errands in the neighborhood.  We had the veggie dumpling and veggie rice rolls as well as veggie egg rolls. Generous portion! Clean table, bathrooms, and floors. Attentive staff. Recommened.
author: Kitty D.

description:
I know a lot of people come here because of Rachael Ray, but honestly - we first went there in SPITE of her. We didn't even know she'd been there until we were on our way up to the dining room, and by then, we were so hungry we didn't care. (Not Rachael Ray fans, if you couldn't tell...)

This restaurant serves dim sum off a menu, not carts, and they offer combo-like set meals, which we share. It's a good mixture of different dim sum items, from egg rolls to dumplings to sticky rice and dessert. 

The food is good, what you expect from dim sum. We've never gotten anything other than dim sum when eating here, so I can't speak to their entrees, but other people seemed to enjoy the food. 

They've never been busy, in all the times we've been in. The service is quick, and you can get in, get fed, and get on your way fast, which I appreciate when I'm on vacation.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Randomly stumbled upon this dim sum place in Chinatown. I was skeptical at first since it's got Rachel Ray on the window. But it ended up being really good dim sum!

The restaurant is on the 2nd flour, and is very clean, roomy, and quiet. On a Sunday, it wasn't packed like other places. There aren't any carts - you have to order a la carte off the menu. Every dish comes fresh.

I have to say the overall quality was really good! I was really surprised by the flavors and attention to detail.

Shrimp dumpling - must get! The rice flour wrapping was really good and they add some crab inside, which makes the flavors richer.

Rice noodle wrapped youtiao - this was really good! The youtiao wasn't overfried and was crispy. Usually this dish can be too oily and overwhelming, but it wasn't like that at all.

Rice noodle wrapped beef - they put some water chestnut and cilantro in the meat filling. It's really refreshing and has a crunchy texture.

Soy paper wrapped meat - also has cilantro, which I think adds to the flavor.

I'd definitely come back here with a bigger group to try more of their other dishes!
author: Sherry L.

description: So gooood! We went for the Dim Sum. Everything was outstanding and made to order. We sat by the window and had a lovely view. Great decor, great service, great company. Will be coming back for more when in SF.
author: Donna M.

description:
I grew up eating a lot of Chinese food and so I think I know the difference between high-quality and blah, not so great. Unfortunately, this food just didn't impress me, The prices were certainly impressively high. $12-14 each dish - eeks! 

The service was excellent, but I think it is needed to draw in tourists. You know to question a restaurant right away when there are no Asian people eating there! 

A friend took me here because he thought it was the best in Chinatown. LOL. Unfortunately, he has not eaten a lot of Chinese food and the recommendation came from the restaurant owner's family next-door! (He didn't understand that it's customary in Asian and other countries to recommend your cousin's restaurant first). 

The Mongolian beef wasn't bad though a bit spicy and when she asked me how spicy, she told me they had already made it. So, what did they do, microwave it? That would explain why the dishes come so fast. The shrimp was starting to go bad too.

There was something wrong with the sweet-and-sour pork. We had two bites and then never touched it again. Tasted as of the pork was bad to me although he thought it was the sauce. It was obvious we didn't like it, and I think the waiter should've asked us if there was anything wrong with it. Sadly, my friend paid for it, though I don't think he should have because we ordered another dish. My friend also got very sick to his stomach afterword, so there definitely was something suspect.

There are plenty of good Chinese restaurants in Chinatown. Unfortunately, I would not agree this is not one of them.
author: Miss K.

description: Good food. We wondered and yelped many places in the area and most where 1-2 stars. Yikes! We finally saw this place and had decent reviews. The food was good, the place was clean, and the staff was attentive. I wouldn't drive here just to eat, but if you're in the area it is a good choice.
author: David S.

description:
There are many Chinese restaurants to choose from in San Francisco, and because I work nearby, I've tried many of them. So far, Oriental Pearl, in my opinion, is by far one of the best ones in the city.

I've never eaten in the restaurant since I do take-out all the time, but I eat from their menu about two or three times a week. I usually order Mongolian Beef or Kung-Pao Chicken from their lunch special menu. Both dishes are amazingly delicious, but I enjoy the tenderness and rich flavor of the Mongolian Beef. I've tried this dish in many other restaurants before and none of them come close to Oriental Pearl's. 

They make it perfect. The beef is very tender and not tough, perfect ratio of beef to onions and all the other major ingredients. It's just simply delicious. The best part is that at the time of writing this review, if you order this dish, or any other for that matter from their Lunch Special menu on weekdays between 12PM - 3PM, it costs only $9.00! This includes steamed rice and a small bowl of soup.

I've never dined inside of the restaurant, therefore I cannot comment on their service. But when I call in the order, the staff is always nice and friendly and the food is usually ready in ten minutes. And when I pick up the food, the dining room is very clean and inviting and the staff is warm and friendly. The only reason for 4-stars instead of 5, is because the Mongolian Beef is slightly more greasy or oily than it should be. But that's just THAT particular dish and not all of them.

Regardless, if you're ever in the area and find yourself craving some Chinese food, Oriental Pearl at 760 Clay Street is a definite must on your itinerary!
author: Joseph R.

description: Nice place to bring people, great service (better than most places in Chinatown), good menu, and the food is decent.  We went at an early hour and had very attentive service.  For quality of food, I wouldn't go out of my to eat here, but if I was entertaining business clients or family, it would be on my list.
author: Mike W.

description: Like the former Asian customers said, no self-respected Chinese customer should eat here, for this portion is really overpriced, and the food isn't delicious at all and that's when we are quite hungry, water is not free, I don't think this place is dedicate enough to do this, when you come in, you can see there's almost no Asian customer here, quite disappointed, PLZ don't come here...
author: Bruce W.

description:
This place is deep in the middle of Chinatown. 

The Good
Service was fantastic, food wasn't too bad. I ordered the lemon chicken and it was good. Being able to get a table on a Saturday night in SF isn't always easy. 

The Bad
The price wasn't too my liking for the portion I paid for. The food was good not great. But when I saw the bill I felt the price wasn't fair. Usually Chinese food is known for giving you more food than you can handle, not this place.

The Ugly
Nothing, place was great. Didn't have to wait long and service was good. Food tasted fune

I would recommend giving it a try in SF. You can try other Chinese restaurants but this one is always available to try. Remember to bring your wallet.
author: James J.

description: A low-profile yet Michelin-recognized restaurant on a relatively uncrowded Chinatown side street. This is the kind of place we're all looking for, right? Uh, no. We made a reservation and were glad we did. The dining room was full and folks were seated on steps outside the restaurant, right smack in the way, waiting for tables to open-up. As has been noted in other reviews, fellow customers were all tourists, none of of them Asian - uh-oh. The food was high-priced meh. I don't know if I have ever rated a Chinese joint for its steamed rice, but it was horrible, like last week's Uncle Ben's. Don't waste your time and money.
author: Steve L.

description:
This is a disgrace to all Chinese restaurants everywhere. If you like terrible slow service, greasy meat, small portions, unfriendly waiters, and grim decoration, then you should try Oriental Pearl.  We had some Unrecognizable noodles in dark gelatinous sauce. It must have been a mistake.  Then we got a giant steaming dumpling basket.......with four little dumplings. These were actually tasty but not reasonable appetizer portion size. 

Somehow we had appetizers stretched out over 20 minutes almost one bite at a time
