There must be better Chinese food in Chinatown. I promise you can't find anything worse
author: Ben H.

description: We went for lunch at 1pm and were given a dinner menu twice the price and to be honest my Mongolian Beef is superior to theirs I would never go to this Restraunt again!!!
author: Jan O.

description: Oriental Pearl helped me arrange a group dinner for 20. The dinner was a hit! The group loved the set menu, quality of the food and were very happy with the service. Making the reservation and confirming all the details were very easy. Thank you to Rebecca for her help in making this night a success.
author: Katie M.

description: We just arrived in The City and went on Dim Sum reconnaissance.  We were happy to find the Oriental Pearl.  The dim sum offerings were amazing as were the cocktails.  The restaurant was classy with white tablecloth and beautiful floral centerpieces.  Very nice oasis of quiet and class in the midst of Chinatown.
author: Jeff S.

description:
RUN SCREAMING! This place sucks, and I can't find a nice way of putting it. To be clear, I love SF's Chinatown and almost always find awesome places to eat, no matter how "hole in the wall." Not this place, and so not for this price.

We were in the mood for a little snack, nothing much, so we ordered the appetizer platter for 2, which came with egg rolls, potstickers, dumplings, and shrimp balls. For $16.50. Please keep that price point in mind. What we got - one egg roll, cut into 4 pieces. 2 potstickers. 2 shrimp balls. 4 dumplings. By my mind, that's almost $1.83 per piece - they better be good. Uh, no. The shrimp balls were pretty good, everything else was substandard. The best part were the beef dumplings, which were raw in the middle. Plus, they charged us $3.75 for a pot of really awful tea.

This place is a huge ripoff and you can probably get better Chines food in Tulsa or something.
author: Deb G.

description:
If you're looking for a nice, authentic, and clean Chinese restaurant then this is your place!!! So glad our hotel concierge recommended this place, seriously a hidden gem. We got there 30 minutes before closing and the two people working were nothing but nice!! Everything we ordered was delicious, especially the BBQ Pork appetizer. 
If you're in SF you should definitely try this place!!!
author: Enza R.

description: Asked the hotel for a Chinese recommendation and off I went. Horrible is all I can say. The reason for 2 stars was at least the service was good. Avoid this place if you want tasty food.
author: b r.

description: Upscale for Chinatown, this restaurant has traditional Americanized Chinese food. The best dish was the honey walnut prawns. The Peking duck was very disappointing. It was dry and not served well.  The service was fine.
author: Michael B.

description:
Saw this on $40 a day with Rachel Ray a while ago, so I was eager to try this place when I saw it... 
Word to the wise, expect a wait!! It is upstairs along a pretty shady street in Chinatown. The place looks a little questionable, but is packed every Saturday from what one of the other patrons told us. 
The service was great, they were very warm once we were seated. We have a family of four and ordered the egg flower soup (two thumbs up), Kung pow prawns, sweet and sour chicken, and chicken chow mein. The egg flower soup was so good!! The Kung pow prawns were awesome. The sweet and sour chicken was just as we expected, but the chicken chow mein was out of this world!!! We should have ordered more, only for leftovers...
I highly recommend this place!!
author: Lisa T.

description: Best food I had in San Francisco this trip. Second floor restaurant in Chinatown, has an elevator but it was kind of hidden. Surprised at how elegant it was inside after the dingy exterior. Service was great, with servers making helpful suggestions for the meal we had in mind and bringing everything nice and hot. There was a good selection of vegetable dishes, food was fresh, very tasty and sauces not overdone. Surprised to read a few reviews criticizing the quality, portions, and prices of the food. Our friend who was a professional chef loved it, and portion sizes were reasonable: we came hungry and got one entree each, with leftovers for each of us. Most seafood entrees were between $17.50 and $24.50, which is not unusual even in cities with lower cost of living. Only thing is you order rice separately and the portion is rather small, about one cup. Would definitely go there again, but I don't recommend it if you expect a place with American-size portions.
author: Laura H.

description: Tasty, clean, good service and nice atmosphere. Parking available around the corner.
author: Andres F.

description:
Tried this place last night. Seated quickly by friendly staff. Ordered hot tea, appetizer sampler platter, spicy green beans w tofu, and beef chow fun w satay sauce. Did not know there would be a charge for tea, appetizers were good and came w that little carved carrot bird, green bean dish was excellent, chow fun was good but might have been better w another kind of sauce.

May come back....or may keep searching in SF.
author: Shawn G.

description: This restaurant was fabulous!!!!!  The food was fresh, tasty, and served hot.  The service was wonderful as this is obviously a family owned restaurant.  If you find yourself in Chinatown, you must try this place.  I'm a picky eater, and this was perfect.
author: Lucky G.

description: Beautiful atmosphere, attentive service, and delicious food. We were all happy and full by the end of our meal. We highly recommend the peking duck. Thankful to Yelp for the suggestion!
author: Anon Y.

description: Throughly enjoyed our lunch. My suggestion would be to try the egg custard tarts. Flakey, light crust like that is very, very difficult to achieve. Kudos!
author: Kari C.

description:
We were pointed this way by my Uncle-in-law, who said it was "THE BEST CHINESE FOOD HE'd EVER HAD!" and indeed when we arrived in San Fran on Tuesday evening, this is where we headed, but found out it was Reservation Only that evening.  Not to be deterred, we decided we'd come back another day.  That day was Friday evening, our last night in the city.

We got there a little before 6pm, just shy of our reservation time, it should have been hopping on Friday night, but the place was only 1/2 full, there was no wait time and we were immediately shown to a table.  It was stuffy, there was no air on, no windows open. Given that we'd walked over a mile to get there, this was.. slightly uncomfortable, but after sitting for a bit, we acclimated. 

We ordered Iced tea (BIG MISTAKE) and our food, along with hot tea and ice water.  The Hot tea was delicious, but the Iced Tea was Rose and it was like drinking your grandmother's hand lotion. It was REVOLTING.  My husband ordered Hot and Sour soup that was .. oily and burnt flavoured, and our friend tried some too, immediately pushing it away, there wsa something other than tofu in it and given he's a vegetarian, it was off his menu.  

Mongolian beef, General Tso's and Almond chicken were our mains and they were all flavourful, I found it odd that we had to pay for steamed rice, that it didn't come as part of the meal. I suppose I shouldn't be surprised, they are milking the Rachel Ray & Zagat recommendations. If given the choice, I might not come back. The food was ok, the service, well they were certainly attentive, right down to putting the food on your plate and in your bowl for you. That's a little over done for me.
author: Dianna B.

description: Bad, bad food. Food was drenched in goopy sauce. It reminded of the green slime from Nickelodeon. Expensive too. One cup of wonton soup was $14 and it was average at best. And service was exceptionally slow. I'm sorry to be so negative but I was so disappointed.
author: Kent K.

description: I've been to this restaurant last weekend and loved it! The restaurant is very Chinese with a spaced out and big dining area. The bathrooms are super clean! The service is great! The food is cooked fresh, warm, and delicious! There is a good variety of food to choose from! The place is clean and fancy with Chinese paintings and dark features! I'd come here again!
author: Connor B.

description: This place is a hidden gem with some of the best dim sum I have ever had, especially the Calamari with Spicy Salt. Just do yourself a favor and place 2 orders. This place is never too busy so you can always score a table, and they have a full bar (just saying.)
author: Jane F.

description:
Unforgetable meal with a great crowd.  Attended this restaurant while in San Franciso for a conference.  The Peking duck is to die for! Super tasty and comes wrapped in a flour tortilla. 

We also had the beef chow fun which was cooked perfectly as I liked it. The House fried rice was a great compliment to all our dishes and the appetizer sampler disappeared within minutes reaching our table. Great and tasty food!

The warm Japanese sake recommended by our waiter was also a great choice. 

Well worth the scenery and walk to China town.
author: Mary S.

description: This place is the worst! They had no customer service, dirty and served us with cold food! This is very unacceptable and disappointing! While eating there, I saw rats running and droppings in the corner. Very disgusting! WARNING! Please think twice before eating at this place!
author: Fred W.

description: Being borned and raised in Hong Kong, I know authentic dim sum when I taste it.  Our hotel staff recommended this restaurant so we decided to give it a try. This place is located in Chinatown and caters to tourists. The locals do not eat here. Food is full of fillers and no real ingredients. I wish I didn't eat here.
author: Stella V.

description:
Reasons why I choose this dimsum place over all the others:

1. There's NEVER a wait. I've been here 4 times now and each time I was seated right away. In fact, this last time, there wasn't another single person in the restaurant.
2. Despite the lack of people, the dimsum is pretty good. Frankly, they're all the same in my eyes but this one is still really good without the long wait that you'd get somewhere else.
3. The service here is really friendly and nice. No carts though if you're into that sort of thing but you can still order the same goodies, just without the carts being pushed around.

Note: There's a restaurant sign outside the restaurant but when you go through the doors, walk up the stairs and it'll be on your right.
author: Diana Y.

description:
We headed here for dinner based on decent Yelp reviews and a recommendation from our hotel's concierge. Unfortunately, our dinner was not great. While this restaurant wasn't awful, there just has to be better Chinese food in the area. This is Chinatown in San Francisco!!

On the plus side, we had a nice hot meal here. There was no wait to eat even though the restaurant was packed and the waiters and waitresses were all very friendly.

However, the food here was not good. The fried rice was the worst. It had what seemed to be bacon bits in it along with mini shrimp. The cashew chicken was also questionable - it was hard to tell the mushrooms from the bits of chicken in it. The sweat and sour pork was good which made up a bit for the other dishes.
author: Audrey P.

description:
BEWARE!  We were tricked into ordering an appetizer we didn't want.  The hostess came by our table with a dish and said, "Our cook just made this.  Would you like to try?"  Assuming it was free (never assume!) we said sure!  Well, they charged us $7.00 for a 2"X4" puff pastry thing filled with about a teaspoon of meat.

They also gave me the wrong order.  When I said this wasn't what I ordered, they refused to correct their mistake.  Luckily, my boyfriend was hungry so he ate it.   I had to order an extra plate.

Food was average, and I will NEVER go here again!!!
author: Anna J.

description: We had a party of 7. Out of the way GEM! The food was superb, the staff professional and the dining room elegant. If this place were near my house, I would eat there everyday!
author: Sherry T.

description:
Came here for dinner with my sister. Great, clean space and very friendly service. We ordered a sampling of the dim sum (6 pieces for about $8 -- quite expensive) which was just okay. We ordered 1/2 peking duck -- they prepared the wraps for us which was a nice gesture (but I prefer to prepare it for myself). Was yummy, but instead of green onions, they provided a mixture of green onions and carrots (prefer only the green onions). We also ordered the mongolian beef with brown rice, which was delicious. 

Overall, everything was great. Would definitely come back!
author: Siv L.

description:
We came here thanks to Yelp! We had plans to dine at R&G as always for their salt and pepper crab but due to the huge wait there and the fact that no one was attending to people arriving I yelped "salt and pepper crab" and found the oriental pearl. And what a pearl this place is. I'm glad we found it.

As other reviews point out the entrance can be deceiving but just walk in, head upstairs and a great dining experience awaits.

In fact we preferred Oriental Pearl over R&G. The crab was sublime and infinitely better. So much more flavor some. Staff were amazing. Welcoming and polite and always checking how things were. Contrast to the rush and aloofness at R&G..... Oriental Pearl is a much more intimate and relaxed dining. 

The Mongolian beef is also excellent as is the hot and sour soup. 

I thoroughly recommend Oriental Pearl. I can't wait to go back.
author: Phill R.

description: Food was a mixed bag.  For the most part it tasted like typical takeout fair.  Mixed vegetables arrived with meat and had to be sent back.  Reworked dish was delivered quickly but under cooked to the point that bokchoy and green beans were practically inedible.  Kung pao shrimp had decent flavor but shrimp were very small.  Chicken in a shredded potato basket was the most interesting plate and had good flavor.  Overall, pretty average..  Recommended by our concierge, but we would not go back.
author: S. H.

description: Wanted to try this place since it popped up on Yelp as a place for dim sum! Stopped by on the 4th of July and they were closed. Hopefully I'll get a chance the next time I visit
author: Day M.

description:
It was okay. The menu was extensive, and the servers and owners pressured me to eat more than half of it by repeatedly bringing me plates of food that I didn't order. I just wanted some simple beef with water chestnuts. The owner, who took my order, pressured me to order an expensive seafood dish. After a few minutes, she returned with a steamed bun, which I said I did not order, and she replied, "well, do you want it?" No. No, I do not. But it didn't stop there: three more unordered, not-free appetizers were brought out to my table by three other staff members. After I ate my actual meal, it continued with staff refusing to bring me my check, bringing me more and more unordered food!

I think it's comical now, but at the time, I was really annoyed, and felt like I was getting a never-ending, high-pressure sales pitch during what should have been a simple early lunch. Even more curious, nobody else in the restaurant seemed to be receiving this treatment. 

I'm not cheap, I tip well, I was a party of one and ordered a drink and one lunch special - not a napkin and some water - and I arrived before the lunch rush. There were probably three other tables seated in the entire dining room at that time, and nobody was beating down the door waiting for a table. I will never go back to this place.
author: Austin J. A.

description:
Probably classify this place as a diamond in the rough. 
It was recommended by the concierge at the Westin St Francis, as being a non touristy place in Chinatown to eat. By the sketched out look on the wife's face as we walked up we figured either we found a sweet place or we should start speed walking the other way.
We walked upstairs to this little place.. White table cloths and red napkins. The service was great people were extremely friendly and the food was delicious! (Not very often I eat left overs on vacation). We had the combo A and added chicken chow mien, everything from the dim sum to the main course was delicious! Highly recommend this place!!
author: Nate E.

description: This place has been recommended by friends. My party and I came here and it was AMAZING!!! Get the General Tsao chicken and shrimp fried rice!!!
author: Martha V.

description:
I'm from Texas, so maybe I'm easily impressed by Asian cuisine, but this was the best dang Chinese food I've ever had.

Our phones had all died so we had no idea where to eat in Chinatown. One of our group noticed a restaurant where a large group had just entered, just off the main Chinatown drag. Probably the best random restaurant decision we've made. And there were no girls handing us menus and coaxing us to come on in (their food is good enough that they don't need it, I guess).

We had the Prawns with Honey Glazed Walnuts (freakin delicious), the General Tso's (pretty dang good - this was my choice because I'm an American sucka), and the Eggplant / Pork Clay Pot, which was the clear winner of the night.

I mean, the Eggplant and Pork Clay Pot was so good. Sooo goood. One of the best meals I've had in a long time. I can't even describe it because I've had nothing like it in my life.

Was a great way to end a day in San Francisco.
author: Dan E.

description:
I was looking for a restaurant in Chinatown for lunch and was pointed to the Oriental Pearl.  

Sometimes I even surprise myself, I ordered shell on steamed prawns with garlic sauce.  Generally when I encounter a cooked shrimp with it's tail still on in a restaurant it evokes an almost violent response from me.  So why would I order a dish that is entirely shell on shrimp?  I don't know, but it was yummy.  I also had the egg flower soup with vegetables and that was very good, possibly the best I've ever had.  

With Chinatown overflowing with restaurants I think you've gotta be realllllly good at what you do here.  The Oriental Pearl wasn't bad, but I think I'd try a couple more places before returning.
author: Kate M.

description: This is our second time here.  The first time and second time was amazing and the service was superior. We were in and out in about 1 hour.  I had the Shrimp with walnuts they were amazing, the waitress said everyone asks for the recipe.
author: Jackie B.

description:
A 5 star dim sum spot in Chinatown!  White tablecloths too!

You wouldn't know it from the street, but this restaurant serves up delicious dim sum every day of the week.  You have to walk under a faded awning & up some ratty stairs to the dining room, but once you enter it is very nice inside.  It seems that mostly tourists dine here, but the food is delicious so don't let the lack of local Chinese folks deter you.

I came with a group of 8 on a Friday.  We had a reservation for noon but it was not needed as the restaurant did not fill up.  The staff were all very friendly (a rarity in Chinatown) & gave us some suggestions as we tried to decide what to order.  They don't push around those little dim sum carts (darn), but the menu is pretty extensive, having both a dim sum & a regular menu from which to order.  It was all overwhelming since there were so many of us & we all wanted different things so I just sat back & let everyone else decide.

The best bites were:

Shrimp & chive dumplings
Spicy string beans with ground pork
Chinese broccoli
Taro cake
Calamari with salt & pepper

I know we ordered a few other dishes, but these were my faves.  The prices were very reasonable.  We all ate enough to fill our bellies & it only cost $13 per person!

My new fave non-dingy Chinatown restaurant.
author: Erin S.

description: The service alone is 5 star. So friendly and just wonderful and patient. Also the food selection is great. Mongolian beef, potstickers, salt and pepper shell on prawns, all great
author: Ashley S.

description: They have a must Try pecking duck and the marinade duck chiu chow style are great also the service is great not that much of a long line but it's a bit pricey
author: Ashley B.

description:
We went for dinner.  Don't let the lack of decor (think ugly ceiling panels and cheap chairs covered with plastic - very seedy from the outside) fool you.  The food was really good!  We had mini spring rolls, General Gao's chicken, Mongolian beef and vegetable chow mein.  

The only fault I can give it is that my husband grabbed his chair seat as he sat down, he didn't realize the seat came up, he sat on it and badly smashed his fingers.  So just be cautious of the cheap chairs.

Slightly overpriced, but in line for SF.
author: Liz B.

description:
Really, really good dim sum and other greasy goodness - with exceptional service. 

My folks and I were looking for a place to grab some Chinese, and Oriental Pearl was one of the first restaurants to pop up on search.  Google search, ya didn't let me down!

We ordered what appeared to be cha siu wrapped in pastry crust, fried taro, pork siu mai, gai lan, the fried turnip cake, a spicy eggplant with pork lunch special, and a beef short rib dish (yes, we love to eat).  

The lunch specials were pretty good, but the dim sum was really something to rave about.  The kitchen staff seemed to have a special eye for detail.  Things like perfectly brushing the gai lan with a nice layer of oil, serving the fried turnip cakes with a nice, crisp pan-fried crust, and bringing out the food hot (and it seemed to order) made a really big difference.  Even the humble, siu mai had an exceptional texture (more coarse ground) and a richer, porkier taste.  

The service was also superb - probably the best I've had at a dim sum restaurant.  Most dim sum places just want you in and out; however, exceptional attention was paid to taking plates away, refilling tea, etc.

I'd definitely recommend this place to anyone who visits SF Chinatown.
author: Julian S.

description: Very solid Chinese.  Hot and Sour was very good, as well as a tofu dish with mushrooms.  Place was clean and the service was very good.  Kind of in an odd second floor setup, but it works.
author: Sean M.

description: Absolutely wonderful! Will definitely be back!  Had potstickers, shrimp and walnuts and chicken chow mein
author: Kelsey M.

description:
Took the kids to Chinatown so we could pick up cheap fireworks, and trusting the Yelp reviews, we tried the Oriental Pearl.  Very nice.

Place has been renovated, so it's very clean.  Wait staff is quite, but super efficient.

Food was excellent.

Peking Duck - Crispy on the outside, juicy on the inside.  Served with plumb sauce.  Very good.

We had a spicy beef dish, pork with snow peas (peas were perfectly done, crisp), walnut shrimp (I didn't taste the walnuts because my middle kid picked them all out), and a very nice fried rice.  Best of all, though was a Dungeness crab dish.  That crab was probably swimming under the Golden Gate hours early.  Excellent.

Fruit juice concoction for the boys, Mai Tai's for Mom & Dad.  

All in all, a very nice find.
author: Bob G.

description: Great restaurant and service. We went on a Saturday and it started to fill up around 7pm. Food was good not greasy. We had the peking duck, house fried rice and spicey chicken. Everything was fresh. A little bit of a hike from Union Square area but worth it.
author: Bonita R.

description: Food was quite delicious and service was on point. Highly recommend this place to dine.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Waitress sat down at a table beside mine to eat her dinner with the other wait staff. 
Ordered bacon and sausage with mushrooms and greens - horrible. 
This place came highly recommended and It was a waste of time and money for me
author: Kevin L.

description:
I've been here a few times for lunch during the week, and it's always been exceptional! 

Made-to-order Dim Sum is always a favorite in my book. I always get a side of greens to cut all the fat (either Chinese Broccoli, or bok choy as a side). I also really like there lo mein noodles, and salt and pepper calamari. All there dim sum has been pretty solid in my book. 

Also, don't forget to order the sesame balls! Hot and fresh to order, and oh so tasty!
author: Angela F.

description: This is a really good place to have a fine, reasonably priced, tasty meal.  As the Empress of China has closed which is a tragic loss to China Town in San Fran, this place is really good.  Everything we ordered we loved.  The view is nothing like the Empress had but it was a very pleasant, clean place, great service and well prepared food.  It is a bit hard to find but it is really good and worth a visit.
author: Nick C.

description: All the food and the service were good. If we lived in SF we would go again but would try somewhere else if we lived here.
author: Paula R.

description: Great dishes!! Large portions. Nice staff. Clean restaurant. We got beef and general zou chicken (not sure how to spell it). Didn't need any kind of appetizers.
author: Idan B.

description: Food was great but small portions, kind of pricey for the amount of food you get, service was horrible as only had two servers with a busy restaurant. Bathrooms were clean. 2 stars bc of the service.
author: Mike M.

description: Dim sum was the best I've ever had! Wow-the highlights: the fried calamari was perfectly seasoned, lightly breaded with a slight kick. The shrimp & scallion dumplings were humongous and oh so good! Service was friendly and top notch! The place was easy to find. Will be back...probably tomorrow! :)
author: Lola Z.

description:
we went here as a friend knew about rachael ray's positive reviews.

it was pretty good!
they don't do the carts, you order from a menu

some pictures would have been helpful
everything was good.

the service was good.

nothing to complain about except they should have pictures.
author: Brian K.

description: While visiting San Francisco I had the pleasure of dining here. I was walking through Chinatown and asked a local of an authentic Chinese restaurant and he recommended Oriental Pearl. Although it is a little pricey, it's worth it. My boyfriend and I spent $60 on hot & sour soup, a combination of dim sum, cashew almond chicken, sweet & sour pork and oriental pearl rice (combination with pork, chicken and shrimp). From the delicious food and great ambience, I highly recommend giving this place a try if you're in Chinatown!
author: Christina A.

description: What a great dining experience! From the outside you would not know what a lovely dining room was to be found.. Great food and service .   Our waiter made excellent suggestions that added to our dining experience. Good was excellent !!
author: Linda P.

description: Great friendly service, warmly greeted as soon as we walked in.  Clean, quiet and well kept restaurant. When ordering dim sum stick to the dumplings.  All were delicious.  Don't get the Siu Mai (had better in many places which is odd because it's such a staple).
author: Lori T.

description:
We have been coming here for years. I'm from Calgary originally and every time we would visit the Bay Area we would always make a stop here for Dim Sum. In fact the Dim Sum was so good here we just stopped getting it in Calgary. We'd always regret the Calgary Dim Sum place and wish we were in San Fran.

The prices are really reasonable, and the service excellent. The only thing that docks a star for me is the atmosphere. It feels like you are eating in an office building not a restaurant. Florescent lights and paper covers the tables. They could use some decor. I suppose if they did renovate the prices would rise. 

Check this place out! We love it!
author: Chris S.

description:
We had lunch there twice during a business trip at San Francisco. We tried roasted duck, cod fish with bokchoy, vegetable fried rice and duck chow fun. All of them tasted REALLY delicious!!    

First, the roasted duck is definitely a must-have dish, even though somebody in the previous review mentioned that the duck might not be crispy. Personally, this is the best roasted duck place I've ever had so far in US.

Second, the ingredients are very fresh. And the dishes are not salty and greasy at all. They kept a PERFECT balance between the amount of food and the seasoning they put into the dishes, which is great, given that in many Chinese restaurants, the food are usually greasy and with too much sauce on the top.

Third,  aside from the delicious food, their service was GREAT!! All the waitors and waitresses are nice, friendly and patient. Consider that it was the first time we visited there and I had many questions to ask before ordering, they were so nice and patient to answer all of my questions, which made our dining experience really joyful.
author: Lilien C.

description:
A huge group came for dinner and they were very accomodating. They set a menu for us about $25 per person which wasn't too bad price-wise.

All of the food items they brought to us were really nothing special. Chinatown in SF, I had really high expectation, but I wasn't blown away at all.

Not sure what other Chinese places to check out, but I'd look elsewhere. You're in Chinatown, so I bet you could throw a rock and either hit an old Chinese lady or a better restaurant.
author: Taylor A.

description: Dinner here was wonderful.  I wanted Dim Sum, but the place we went to nearby was closed for renovations.  This had good reviews so I decided to try it out.  I am glad that I did.  It was a nice sit down place with very attentive and polite staff.  The Dim Sum Sampler appetizer was ok.  Not the best that I've had.  The Almond chicken with Cashew Nut hit the spot as did the Oriental Fried Rice.  It had the amazing Chinese sausage that tasted like cured pork with a pineapple sweetness.  The star of the meal was the Prawns with Honey Glazed Walnuts.  You need to order this.  It is not a dish I've had anywhere else.  Our server said that it was a house specialty.
author: Jessica E.

description: Delicious.  Our server recommended a dish, prawns and walnuts in honey sauce and it was delicious.   We also ordered the cashew chicken but it was a little bland.  I will definitely go back, but will let the server recommend more dishes.   Price was very fair for the amount of food.   Service was great and with no reservations we only waited  10 minutes for a table.
author: Carol C.

description:
The food was 3 star.

The location is 5 star, in Chinatown.

The ambience is typical Chinese, 4 stars.

Our waitstaff was adequate, so 3 stars.

You are safe eating here!!
author: Best P.

description: My husband and I were quite disappointed because our all time favorite restaurant in China town, Empress of China,  was closed for good. But thanks to a nice guy we met at one of the stores told us that Oriental Pearl was even better, we had to come and try it. This restaurant is so delicious. We had the prawns and scallops with vegetables and the taste was amazing. You have to try the spicy green beans with tofu; you will not be disappointed. The service was impeccable! We will be back again and again!
author: Christina H.

description: This is a very nice restaurant in the heart of Chinatown. Only $15corkage fee.
author: Michael B.

description: Took my mom here for her birthday dinner and it was right before the Thursday dinner rush at 5pm. Great noodles and impeccable service.
author: Junica B.

description: The food was pretty good, only giving 3 star because of the portions. The A and B family dinners are almost $30 a person and our 2 grown-ish boys left hungry. The portions would've been ok for 2 people but not near enough for 4! Should not still be hungry after spending $130 before tip!
author: Jeff P.

description: This restaurant is a little pricey but if you are looking to splurge on some outstanding Chinese this is the place. The Peking duck is exceptional. Try to resist putting too much of the delicious sauce on as the flavored as they serve it are really well balanced. We had the tofu and seafood soup and it was delicately layered with flavor. Assorted appetizers were good and the fried rice was superb. Again resist putting soy on the fried rice as it looks light but the favors layer and it tastes light and fresh as is. Definitely a sophisticated Chinese experience.
author: Dean T.

description:
I can't get over how much I love this place! This is my favourite place to go for Dim Sum. Hy husband and I always come to this place whenever we visit the Bay Area. You'll find it located just off the beaten track of SF China Town on the second level. The staff are very friendly and the food service is very quick, as Dim Sum should be!

We'll often get the Chinese dumpling, sweet pork, Chinese broccoli and sesame bun. We may only come here once a year but every time we come it's just as good as we remember it.
author: Roz M.

description: This place was fantastic. It was friendly service, great food- and just a great vibe! We were stuffed full of good food and will return whenever we're back in San Fran:)
author: Sophie M.

description: Concierge at the Marriott Marquis recommended this place and I ate there twice during my stay. Very clean dining area, friendly stand attentive service, and good selection of food.
author: Chris S.

description: We come here every time we're in San Francisco. I haven't found another place that serves prawns with candied walnuts as good as they make it here. We usually eat an early dinner so the restaurant is quiet and the servers attentive. I also like the hot and sour soup, along with pot stickers, for starters.
author: Laura G.

description:
One night is San Francisco following a great week in Napa, and our hotel recommended oriental pearl.  
Five of us, all ordering different dishes and not one would I recommend. 
Bland  and boring would be the best description.  
We all love Chinese food, so this was a bitter disappointment and a bad way to end our vacation.
author: Herman F.

description:
The food lacks flavor.The tables are too close to each other I can hear the other customers chewing their food.A large aquarium is situated at the dining area.The giant tilapia's are better off donated to Ripley's believe it or not. They are gliding on the mossy glossy aquarium glass.I guess,the janitor fish is too lazy to clean it up.
Back to the food,it really lacks flavor.Im too young to be on a renal diet.Hellooo,what happened to ajinomoto msg??
author: Maria Gerona L.

description: Ok after checking out the reviews on yelp,   plus and minus,  I decided to give this place a chance.  Not disappointed at all. First it was very clean and well kept. The drinks were great. The food was very fresh and tasty.  Now here is the kicker.  I travel alone for my work a lot.  Many authentic Chinese restaurants serve family style for 2 or more. My server suggested an off menu dish that they made for me custom. It was superb.  I also had the vegetable steamed appetizer. All of my food was fresh and wonderful.  If you want a table and good service try this establishment.  If you feel they are not delivering talk to the manager.  They will make it right.
author: Sean D.

description:
For my birthday, the hunny and I decided to head to SF china town as we were wanting to try some authentic chinese food. Not one of those places that has a panda in its logo. We ended " at this place just by chance and luck. I knew we had made the right decision after seeing rachel ray's plaque amongst others on the wall. The decor appears upper scale with fancy folded napkins and table cloths. But the atmosphere is not stuffy, and perfect for the traveler who wants a break from the speediness of the city.
     We ordered the dim sum appetizer which was delicious and just perfect to start your appetite for the food that is ahead. I ordered mongolian beef and boyfriend ordered chow mien. The chow mien is made with thin noodles, and not thicker spaghetti like noodles which I was accustomed too, but nevertheless it was tasty. Be careful of the monogolian beef as is packs a punch. It is often advertised on menus as being spicy, and the dish turns out to be much more sweet and saucy than spicy. This dish was the opposite. The spicy crushed red peppers left me yearning for my beverage glass. The service was awesome and catering. The lady who helped us was a sweetheart. I highly recommend if you want delicious food in chinatown.
author: Stephanie K.

description:
If you are looking for PF Changs, get out of China Town. If not, this place   was worth the go for us. The people are very nice. They serve you from the family-style plates. They were attentive. I think we stayed past hours. They didn't say a word. A few of the staff just began to have their meal for the evening...which I found pretty neat to see a smart, old fashioned practice alive and well.

The place is what you'd expect. Not sparkley. We had a couple seafood dishes and a couple veggie dishes that were fresh and well prepared.
author: Becky R.

description: Top Notch! We were looking for a little more upscale restaurant to eat at during our visit to San Fran. Clean white table clothes, excellent service. We had our five year old son with us and just ordered a dim sum platter and it was perfect for the three of us! The servers were even great with our son. We will Deff be back!!
author: Amylynn M.

description: best Peking duck in the city!! The salt and pepper crab is a little messy but oh so good. They also make a great Mai Tai. There Dim Sum is house made and fresh. Great staff and they deserve 5 stars
author: Concierge J.

description: This place was awesome! Great food, great service, great atmosphere! Will definitely go back when I'm in San Fran again!
author: Peyton P.

description: Went here for our first night in San Francisco. Great service and lovely food, the crab was delicious!
author: Sam C.

description: This place was recommended by our hotel concierge. Definitely a place that tourists visit vs locals, but still a good choice. The atmosphere feels traditional.  We had the appetizer platter, a variety of options which was tasty.  Then for our entrees we had beef fried rice and almond chicken with cashews. Both were very tasty. I'm not sure how Rachel Ray ate here so cheaply on her former show $40 a day! While prices are reasonable they're not that low! Overall, a good meal and we would return. We also would recommend to others.
author: Michael B.

description: It was disgusting... Walnut shrimp tasted like I was eating shrimp with mayonnaise, was not sweet and it was cold. Combination fried rice was not good at all. Beef and broccoli was yuk. Beef was still red and it was way too tough! Will not recommend this  place to anyone and will not come back!!!
author: Kelly L.

description: Not much to say about this place aside from the fact that the underwhelming food was very overpriced.  Peking duck was below average, skin was not crisp.  It was served in tortillas, with carrots and a scant amount of scallions. Bbq quail appetizer was ok.  Much better spots in Chinatown.
author: Tony V.

description: Selected this place based on yelp reviews. No Asian people eating there, so bad sign. Cool carrot carving decorations. Polite service. Overpriced food. They recommended very americanized dishes to us. Shrimp with candied walnuts were covered with mayonnaise? We went there in search of dim sum, although it was evening. They had a few dim sum items. Peking Duck was cold, and dry tasting, maybe not enough sauce placed in the pancakes. Kind of sad that our family dinner didn't turn out as well as I had hoped. Smelled like smoke even though I couldn't see anyone there smoking. I would not go back.
author: E. M.

description: For authentic Chinese cuisine at a reasonable price, served by an outstanding wait staff, I recommend the Oriental Pearl.
author: Todd H.

description: Typical price-gouging tourist trap. My luke warm duck came 15 minutes before Mary's stir fry. Waiter refused to make eye contact. Cold sake was served with a glass of ice. Rice is extra? Really? Feh.
author: Gary F.

description: Not as good as a couple of years ago when we thought the food was excellent.  We will be looking for a different place for next visit.
author: Roxanne C.

description:
My granddaughter and I made a spontaneous trip to Chinatown on a Monday.  We were early, I guess, because there weren't any restaurants open except grab-n-go places.  We kept walking until we spotted Oriental Pearl.  I found it very open and spacious, but there was only a few of us there, so....

The server helped my granddaughter (8 years old) pick out a noodle dish with her taste preferences.  I started ordering dim sum like I knew what I was doing but the server warned me it was too much food.  I appreciated that!  Especially since the whole lunch ended up costing $30.  I was a little surprised.  I guess the individual dishes add up.

My favorite was the calamari with spicy salt - delicious!  I also had pan-fried shrimp & chives dumpling which was pretty good.  The Shanghai style steamed pork buns weren't all that great but they came with a ginger vinegar dip that was a nice twist on soy sauce.

I'd go again.  Nice service, fresh and fast food.
author: Pamela P.

description: Love this place! A little deep into Chinatown if u are a little skittish as a tourist but worth it! Not a looker from the street by go up the stairs and presto! There are the white tablecloths and friendly staff. The Peking duck is the best in town.
author: Mark B.

description:
Ok I guess. It wasn't horrible, but then again literally everyone in the place was Caucasian. Not a good sign in Chinatown.

The mai tai's had a good amount of booze. Not too much, not too little. We had the dim sum platter. Weird to have beef shiumai. Not a fan, but that's just me. The pork were fine.

It's a sizeable place. Lots of kids. Tank with lobster, all the standards. They were VERY attentive in their service. Kinda made me wonder if they had enough plates in the restaurant. They hovered just itching to pick them up.

I guess I'd go back in a bind.
author: Stacie M.

description: Super awesome dim sum.  The best choice we made was to ask for the recommendations from our servers and their selections were by far the best.  The spicy salt calamari was probably the most surprisingly delicious item we ate am the while meal.  Also the chicken meatball， stuffed eggplant.  Their dumplings were all very good too.  My sons each got a quail and they liked that as well.  Good service especially for Chinatown.  Not sure why this place doesn't have a higher yelp score... Looking at the reviews it seems most of the people with lower scores for entrees so maybe those should be avoided.  I didn't try any of them but I think we had 8 different orders of dim sum and they were all good except the jelly fish.  That wasn't terrible， just not so great.
author: Cranky M.

description: Great food and if you are seated by a window you'll get an excellent view of Chinatown!
author: Lindsay S.

description: Great Chinese food. No dim sum for dinner - for lunch only. Slow service so don't come here to eat in a hurry!
author: James J.

description: Don't let Rachael Ray's photo fool you. This is not authentic Chinese food or anything close to it. It's not good, the only good thing about it is the price.. You get what you pay for. Cheap price, cheap food. The food was bland. Lean Cuisine Chinese food is way better than anything from Oriental Pearl Restaurant. If you want truly amazing Chinese food go to R&G Lounge!
author: Shawn L.

description:
Decor=1-1/2 --bland decoration, white walls and nothing interesting.
Value=2-1/2-see below
Food=3
service=3
Beef Broccoli was ok on par with other chinese restaurants; Walnut Glazed Prawns were real good; Seafood combo was Ok--there was more tofu than seafood.  If it wasn't for the prawns I would of given 3 stars.  Price was $15.95 for prawns and 18.95 for seafood combo.  They charge you for the rice as well.  On the pricey side in my opinion.  If I was a local I wouldn't go again, I would try somewhere else.
author: Mark H.

description:
My wife and I have eaten at Oriental Pearl many times over the past 3 years.  it is probably our favorite chinese restaurant in San Francisco, certainly if measured by the number of times we have eaten there compared with any other Chinese restaurant (we have probably tried a dozen).

The restaurant itself is not fancy and due to the Rachel Ray recommendation it is always busy with tourists.  But we really like the food here and have always had great service.  We order pretty typical items (hot and sour soup, potstickers, various chicken, beef and scallop dishes) and always come away satisfied.  Had the salt and pepper crab once when that was in season and would definitely order that again.

One other plus is that we have always been able to get a reservation on a few hours notice and when we get there we are seated within a few minutes.
author: Richard M.

description:
I totally agree Henry W. review dated on 7/30/2011. If I could give them less than one star that would be a better category. I was there just this past weekend with my boyfriend 8/6/2011 for dinner. First it took us 30 mins to get a number and there were only 2 people in front of us. Long wait to get seated, another 30 mins. I told my boyfriend do not order any sea food after I saw their aquariums. The fish tanks are SO disgusting. Fish and lobsters are stuffed into an undecorated tanks and swim around in brown water. Gross. I wanted to leave, but my boyfriend said "There are a lot of people waiting, perhaps, the food was well worth the wait for its reasonable..."

we ordered:

Deep Fried Shrimp Ball in Chiu Chow Style (4) ....................... 8.75
Sauteed Pea Sprouts with Garlic ........................ 14.75
some rib dish w/ Spicy Salt ( I think it's around $ 8.75)

We waited for another 30 mins for 4 tiny shrimp balls, then we waited for another 25 mins for the other 2 dishes. The very easy to prepare ribs with spicy salt was deep fried and covered in heavy batter (WTF?). The pea sprouts was an overpriced rip-off.

I honestly had no idea why Rachel Ray and AAA gave it a good reviews. I am Chinese, and I am not a picky eater but these food were the worst. I was so embarrassed by the way the restaurant presented their cheap street food.
author: Jessica M.

description:
It's amazing how one persons crap is another ones treasure. There were many good reviews here especially for Peking duck
We even noticed that Rachel Ray was here for one of her shows $40 a day. Well at least we know how she does it now!. She eats crappy food! 

So we decide to go because they make the duck with flat pancakes and not fluffy buns. Flat pancakes is the way to go. We we made a reservation which turned out to be a good idea. There was a line out the door. They seated us as soon as we got there. We ordered two drinks, which arrived in the smallest high ball glass and tumbler we have ever seen. Like made for little people or something. 

Also very strange, when we sat down, we noticed not one table in the restaurant was eating. Then all of a sudden food started coming out. Like we were on a cruise ship or a wedding or something.

Here's what we ordered:

Dim Sum sampler
1/2 duck
Beef with scallions
White rice (They charge extra for rice)

Dim Sum? We ate it but it was not so good. 
Beef and scallions was very good but you could get that anywhere.
Then came the duck. Yuck! Dry, greasy, tasteless, awful. The sauce wasn't even hoisin. 

If you think this is good duck, you don't know good duck.

The only place in the US that does it right is Peking Duck House in NYC on 53rd street between 2nd and 3rd. 

Whoever rated this place good, and especially raved about the duck?......well my friends,..... stop by my house one day for a nice bowl of Spagehtti O'si or some cardboard on toast! Geez !!!!!  STAY AWAY
author: Henry W.

description:
We were sent here by the concierge at our downtown hotel, he highly recommended this place.  Like most Chinatowns in urban America, the area is seedy and decrepit.  Despite our misgivings we went in, based on the rec.  The Pearl is no exception.  

Should have trusted our instincts, developed over years of travel dining, and moved on.

We tried a sampling of a few items.  Their menu posted outside doesn't match the one in the dining room.  No dim sum at night.  OK, fine, we can adapt.  After confusing explanations from the waiter of their a la carte menu (no rice served with dishes??) we finally ordered.  In a nutshell, the food is uninspired and ordinary at best.  A weird flavor dominated one dish we had, the sauted prawns, making the dish unusual and unappetizing.  Prawns the size of 25-30 count shrimp?  Plus it was really oily.  And $15 for an order of fried rice with seafood, with very little seafood and too many scallions.  

I am surprised how highly rated this place is, in a town with so many Asians I would expect more.  I've had much better Chinese in other cities with less predominant an Asian influence.  Just not impressed at all and wouldn't return. 

If this place is supposed to be one of the best, I would hate to sample the average.

Oh yeah, our waiter was just OK, he vacillated between helpful and annoyed at our inability to decipher his largely indiscernible explanation of their offerings.  He would only stay a moment at our table before darting off, promising to return once we figured out what we wanted.  He was impatient with us, yet he stood gabbing with the folks at a table nearby for a long time.  Maybe pandering for a tip.  Service is sub par.
author: Jay W.

description: I loved this restaurant.  Chinatown is so fun in SF and this restaurant sits in the heart of it.  The entrance looks sketchy but once on the 2nd floor, the restaurant is really lovely with nice table clothes and napkins.  I had a simple but delicious lunch which was the sweet and sour pork.  That coupled with the soup made for a delicious lunch.
author: Jim C.

description: We took our family of 4, 2 kids under 12, with another family with 2 kids under 8. Food, and service excellent.  We mainly had Dim Sum dishes, with a few other items as well. Great experience overall.
author: a A.

description: Good selection on the menu, but it's overpriced for the quality level.  They go for an upscale vibe to justify the higher prices but the atmosphere is so dated and desaturated that it doesn't work.  Food was OK, but not worth the price, especially for chinatown.
author: Mike L.

description: Food tastes good, but a bit too greasy.  The wait time is very long between each course, and they are not even that busy!!  We waited for our last course for over 20 min.
author: Jess M.

description: This place is right in the heart of China Town. Slightly upscale with great dim sum. Very clean with excellent service. One of the better places to eat in China Town.
author: Reisha B.

description: Best Chinese food ever. So recommended. My husband is a very picky eater but he absolutely loved their food. We tried the beef fried rice and it was amazing. The Mongolian beef was supper delicious. If you wanna eat in Chinatown you should not miss eating here.
author: Mahsa S.

description: Dim Sum aficionados - look no further. This is the best dim sum my Cantonese wife and I have had in SF Chinatown. The service was polite and relatively fast, and the price was quite reasonable ($30 for two people to fill up on a variety of dim sum).
author: Michael L.

description:
My wife and I go to Oriental Pearl whenever we are in the City because the food is phenomenal, the ambiance is great and the service is excellent.

Our favorite dish is the Peking Duck which gets prepared at the table and rolled up in something similar to tortillas which they call pancakes.  The sauce is addictive.  All other dishes we've ever had have been delicious as well.  We've been here lots of times and never left disappointed.

The ambiance is simple which we love.  Less is more and yet it seems very authentic.  White table cloths and comfy chairs.  It makes the experience so much better.

It seems like the same people have worked here for as long as the place has been open.  They even remember us though we only drop in once every 4 - 6 months.  Part of why this restaurant is so consinstently good is because the owner is there every night.  Their presence undoubtedly creates an expectation of excellence.

We can highly recommend Oriental Pearl and will be back many more times.
author: Hartmut O.

description: The Dim Sum was great!  I also enjoyed the scallops and mushrooms but David's duck casserole was not worth eating.
author: Charity G.

description: Had lunch here yesterday.  The Peking Duck was wonderful.  Other lunch items were pretty typical Chinese food, but well prepared.  The decor is nice.  Not lavish, but not tacky either.  One big advantage for out-of-towners is the very close (and reasonably priced) parking at Portsmouth Square.
author: Janis P.

description: recommended by a woman at the front desk of our hotel. The place was busy and a mix of americans and chinese eating there... we went for dinner. The noodles were a bit too oily for my taste.
author: Steve S.

description: It was enjoyable, but not remarkable. The service was strangely busy, but simultaneously unenthusiastic. I didn't hate it, but I wouldn't do it again. On balance: meh.
author: David G.

description: Excellent service and wonderful food if you like Dim Sum arena. Out of the way location and unassuming from the outside, but quite causlly pleasant on the inside. Recommended.
author: Jim L.

description:
Service was fast and courteous, since I came in on a slow Monday afternoon. I have been meaning to expand my culinary horizons within the Chinatown area. They have a pretty comprehensive menu with set menus for everything from dim sum prix-fixe to fixed meals and lunch specials (that come with tasty hot and sour soup and your choice of rice), but I must say that they are extremely strict on the no substitution rule, and you can only do the set menus IF two or more persons are doing the same set menu. 

I came in craving dim sum and wish they had more of an extensive selection, but they had the usual suspects, har gow, shiu mai, steamed pork buns, potstickers, etc. and a decent selection of the traditional offerings of a Chinese restaurant. I do love the carts that go around at authentic spots that one tends to find at a Cantonese restaurant. They had the white tablecloth, simple decor, and it was clean. The service was good and fast, was not too stifling, the pricing was reasonable (for SF restaurants) and the food was pretty authentic. My cab driver even vouched for them on the way in.

It is pretty centrally located in Chinatown, and they have tons of competition, but it is not bad, and extremely well-priced. My good friend and I enjoyed our lunch there, but either the meal was salty, we were extremely dehydrated, or the glasses were small, because after 2 refills on our diet cokes, we still needed more, and I usually can't finish one can in a setting! I am pretty sure it was priced per re-fill too. Not a hefty charge but when you have tons of re-fills, it adds up!

I will come back, after I check out their competition!
author: Tammy H.

description: Hole in the wall treat, hidden gem goodness. Go for the walnut and prawn (aka shrimp) dish.
author: Pinky L.

description: It's upstairs and hard to see from the outside, but it's definitely worth it.  Service is exceptional even for non Chinatown standards.  The food was one of the best I've had in the area. Very classy and fancy inside. I definitely would come back anytime I want a place away from all the crowds and busy folks.
author: Adam H.

description:
Amazing food and amazing service! After ordering two vegetarian appetizers, the owner came by and suggested the BEST vegetarian entrees. 

Loved it and would come back in a second!
author: Tasha B.

description:
On our last day in San Francisco, my friends and I passed by this place and saw that it was on an episode of Rachel Ray's $40 a Day show so we thought it might be good. The food was not good. It wasn't bad but we were expecting so much more and we realized that Rachel Ray would know NOTHING about what Chinese food is supposed to be like. 

The WORST part?? 

There was a hair on our dumplings. This alone was gross enough right? No! We sent the plate back, telling them there was a hair on it. We were actually very nice about it. We just wanted another plate. After about 5 minutes, the waiter brings out another plate of dumplings. Or so we thought. It was the SAME plate! I knew because I took a before and after picture on my camera and it was VERY obvious. They didn't even bother to rearrange the dumplings. I don't even want to know what they did back there that took them that long to bring out the SAME plate. 

When I pointed this out at the end of the meal, the waitress said "No, it's a different plate." I said, "No, it's the SAME plate. Do you want to see the pictures on my camera?" That's when the waiter that brought the plate to us walked by, picked up the plate, and rudely said that he would take the dish off our bill. 

I would NOT come back to this place simply because I believe what they tried to pull off was so distasteful and disrespectful.
author: lisa p.

description:
I've tried coming to this place twice and I always picked the time that they were closed. Finally I made it! Glad I did too. I went with a large group, my family. The waiter (owner?) made plenty of great recommendations and also asked if anyone had questions which were quickly and descriptively answered. 

On the table we had sweet and sour chicken and shrimp, veg lo mein and chicken lo mein, mongolian beef, chinese fried rice, and peking duck (my favorite). 

If I return I will definitely be getting the duck again!

They gave us a pot of hot tea and for those who weren't used to that -- they got iced tea. However, they didn't like it since it was lychee flavored... oops.
author: Jennifer P.

description: We live in NYC and eat in our Chinatown regularly, and I travel to China for business.  Oriental Pearl has great food! It's a block off the main strip and up the stairs, so not as crowded as other places with better locations. Too bad for those who miss out:  the dumplings are freshly made (i.e., you'll wait a bit for them, rather than pick them from roving carts), as is everything else.  Pork buns, Shanghai-style pork dumplings, veggie spring rolls, rice noodle rolls are our favorites.
author: Rich K.

description: My only stop in chinatown for Xmas. Highly recommended, especially the duck! Great food and service (a unique combo) for c-town.
author: Sharon M.

description:
Went here for dim sum.  Food was okay.  It was decent flavor, a bit greasy, and decent prices for dim sum.  The rest of the menu was pretty much Americanized chinese food.  

Pretty clean.  Bright lights.  Some natural lighting as well.  

Service is friendly, efficient, and they're wearing cute bowties.

Tucked away, near the park.  Not sure about parking in this area.

So, if you want a quiet sit-down place for the lunch rush, go here.  But if you're in for the Wow-effect, skip this place.
author: Fannie S.

description: Much nicer than you'd expect from the street. White table cloths and very attentive service. I had the mini spring rolls and vegetables with mushrooms. I enjoyed everything. Prices are higher than you need to pay in China town for a meal, but if you want a nicer, sit down restaurant this works well.
author: Jim U.

description: We decided on the Dim Sum lunch for two!  Great decision. Everything was delicious!!  And the service was wonderful too. We'll definitely come here again!!
author: Shari L.

description: We had dinner twice here. Everything we ordered was good, especially seafood. Their hot and sour is spicy true to it's name.
author: Omur T.

description: Great experience and food.  I never would have ventured in if I hadn't seen it on Food Network.  Excellent service, excellent food.  Quiet atmosphere.  Loved the hot and sour soup and the Mongolian beef.  Location was great.
author: Theresa B.

description:
I visit the Oriental Pearl every time I am in San Francisco for one thing in particular:  The Peking Duck.  Waiters wrap it in moshu pancakes for you.  Even folks who have never had duck or claim not to like it seem to enjoy it here.  The other food is pretty good too but it's really the duck that brings me back.

I love the attention that the waiters give you here too.  Much more so than at most Chinese restaurants.  They are very professional and spend time at your table.  They help you with serving the food, and as I stated, they do all the hard work for you on dishes like the Duck Mushu.

This place is great for large groups.  They have very generous "family style" meals where you get to try a lot of different dishes as well and the large tables have a rotating centerpiece which makes it easy to get to the dish you want.
author: Adisak P.

description:
This place is great. It was zagat rated so I figured it had to be decent (so far I have not been disappointed from any of the restaurant listed in that book, def a book to get if you want to try some great food).

In the heart of China Town, this place is of a descent size, upper scale with white linen and all, on the wall to your left when first walking in is adorned with pictures of Rachel Ray and local rewards. 

Everything from the appetizers to both mine and my friend dish were Incredible definitely measured up to the high expectations that I had built up. The flavor was light fresh and extremely satifying.Little pricey!! But you can taste the quality and effort put in to it. Nice service as well. I have only been there once and have yet to try some more of there dishes. Looking forward to going back.
author: Shannon H.

description:
FOOD: My God, this place is a disgrace. The Dim Sum is a disgrace. The meat is greasy and disgusting, shrimps are tasteless and FAR from being fresh, and the vegetables have all been over-cooked and soaked in MSG. A plate of vegetable Chow Mein (stir-fried noodles) costs a whopping $10 and it's not even enough to feed one person. Not to mention that it's extremely greasy too. The *only* Dim Sum that's not too bad is the "Beancurd Rolls in Oyster Sauce." Everything else is a total disgrace. Do not come here for Dim Sum. Dim Sum is NOT supposed to be this bad! Argh! Yikes.

DECOR: The interior decoration is characterless, which is worse than being ugly. At least ugly places might have some indivudiality or originality to speak of. The walls in this restaurant are pale white and the whole place feels like a hospital, no less.

SERVICE: Except for ONE waiter from China (he speaks a China-accent Mandarin) who is friendly and attentive, everyone else is indifferent. There's even a thinly-veiled frustration and hostility present in the air. We were there for lunch and there weren't many people there. But still, we received NO service whatsoever (except from that friendly Chinese guy, occasionally). I seriously wonder why....
author: Rachel W.

description: Following the recommendation from our hotel concierge, we were very disappointed with the food. If this is the best Chinatown San Francisco has to offer, we are sadly unimpressed. Bland, bland, bland food. Brown rice was soggy, clumpy, bleh. We tried two different dishes, both were bland and really quite gross.
author: Janelle J.

description:
In town for the weekend game and we wanted some Chinesse food.  People suggested R & G; I called and they said everything had been booked and that they couldn't guarentee a table for my group but said we could wait... We found ended up at the Oreintal Pearl...  It's a hard place to find because its off the main strip but I will tell you it was a damn good place. 

Since we never had been to China Town we decided to go big, dim Sum and vegi egg rolls, sweet and sour chicken, mongolian beef and pork lo mein.  Probably the best Chinesse food weve ever had.  The waiter's were amazing and helpful, not once did any of us have to ask them for anything, They just knew.......

The location is kinda run down and old, but then again in this place what isn't old and run down.
author: R L.

description: So disappointing. Recommended by the concierge at our hotel, a big disappointment for the single Chinese meal we had time for while in the Bay Area. Food seemed laden with MSG, unimaginative, slimy, touristy shlock. Not a single Asian in the entire dining room, stuffed with obvious tourists . Do yourself a favor and skip.
author: Mary W.

description: Ordered the veg. eggrolls and DimSum trio to start...they were so,so. Then came they Sweet & Sour Chicken, Mongolian Beef and the Pork LoMein. The chicken and the noodles were the table favorites. Service was outstanding.  Atmosphere was bland/cold.  Not intimate or romantic but a good place to stop before a night out with friends.
author: Incog N.

description: Simply terrible. I had pork egg rolls and beef chow fun with satay sauce. Bland and unappetizing.
author: Leslie U.

description: Amazing! Tried several times to ass a more detailed review however YELP kept telling me I was too wordy tonight.....that's new. Hopefully this will get posted and this wonderful gem gets another well deserved 5 stars. Thank you to the very gracious staff who were so accommodating regarding my shellfish allergy. Best Valentine's Day dinner.
author: Laura H.

description:
After walking around Chinatown, my friend and I chose this place for our group, for reasons that I'm not entirely clear on. Maybe it was because I recognized the name from Rachael Ray's $40 A Day...or maybe it was because it was closest to where everyone else was going to meet us.

We arrived at 11AM, just as they opened on Sunday. No cute little carts peddling mysterious little steamers. We were given menus and ordered a fixed number of dim sum courses for about $11.

The food wasn't bad. It wasn't the best dim sum, but it really wasn't all that bad.  Their crispy taro thinger (I have no idea what the official name of it is) was really good...but as I told everyone at the table, I can eat dozens of those gut bombs and be happy wherever I am.

Next time, though, I will head a block over and try one of the other places.
author: Tracy S.

description:
3.5 stars for the value and ability to handle large groups.

The hotel said that this was the spot for us...20 lads on a stag aka bachelor dinner before going out on the town. It was a good choice - lots of reasonable food for an accommodating $20 a head.

It's unusual to get such a selection of food on a tight budget, but the first course was peking duck in pancakes. I remember the shrimp and walnuts, the Mongolian beef, chili chicken, fried rice, sugar snap peas and chicken. The chef's even brought out some vege options for our single friend who didn't eat meat.

The only downer was the waiters were pushy on the booze. Not surprising because we all know that's where the money's made. Anyway, all in all the meal was $40 per person as some of us had cocktails and several og 'em ;)

I wouldn't bring my parents here because they're from Hong Kong and used to run a restaurant...aka this is Westerner Chinese food. But I'd bring a date and some mates...
author: Stephen P.

description: Wish there were 10 stars to give! While exploring Chinatown, we considered the many restaurants, but something drew us to The Oriental Pearl and when we saw Rachael Ray had visited, we knew we wouldn't be disappointed! The restaurant was clean and welcoming. The staff was friendly and accommodating.  The food was incredible! I strongly suggest the vegetable egg rolls and General's chicken...far beyond any Chinese I have ever had!
author: Mary S.

description: This place was pretty darn good.  I was surprised at the prices though.  I wouldn't necessarily go back.  There are tons of choices in Chinatown, I was surprised the food wasn't better.  I have no complaints about the food itself.  I just don't feel it was worth the price.
author: Theresa K.

description: The food was good (especially the Peking Duck which I loved) but way too slow.  The dishes came out randomly over a long period of time and by the time the last one came out, so much time had elapsed that we had nearly forgotten it.  I would still return since the duck was so tasty, but speed and service will have to improve for this to become a favorite.
author: Travis H.

description:
As I do every holiday season, I'm out in the Bay Area for a week visiting my family. As is typical with my family, we've hunted for and sampled half a dozen new Chinese restaurants in the area this week. Oriental Pearl was one of the most disappointing. 

The non-dim sum dishes weren't all bad: I'd recommend the Mongolian beef and the jie-lan vegetables stir-fried with garlic and anchovies. The dim sum left a LOT to be desired. I feel like it's pretty hard to mess up shu-mai, and these guys managed to do it. I was also not impressed by the turnip cake or chang-fen.

The one dish that Rachel Ray raved about - chicken meat balls wrapped in egg whites - was fine, but nothing to write home about if you ask me. 

All in all, the food was ok - but why make this stop when there are dozens of amazing authentic Chinese restaurants just down the street?
author: Yuting L.

description: Yum!  Chinese food can be so predictable but this was a wonderful surprise. Everything was so tasty. The staff was relaxed and attentive.  We had the Como B but I would love to try a broader selection of the dim sums. The decor is bright and pleasant;,not especially fancy. Just a little pricey or would have been 5 stars.  Will probably be back when in the area.
author: Duane H.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Saturday night, the place was packed but the staff was prompt, polite and offered great service. The food was great, some of the best I've had. The fried lobster was amazing!!! It was clear from the portions and quality of meat, that they were not cutting corners. 

They have been highly reviewed by Rachel Ray, Zagat and others--- I can see why! Will definitely come back and I recommend you do too!
author: S S.

description:
After dining many times here and only reviewing their dim sum I felt like I really needed to review dinner.

My personal favorites are the. Salt and Pepper Crab, bok choy, snow pea leaves, honey walnut prawns and the Peking duck. You can't go wrong with these items. 

Don't be turned off by all the white people in the restaurant, it's because Rachel Ray reviewed the restaurant and has turned it into a tourist destination. 

The wait for a table can get rather long so book a reservation in advance. Carolyn, the reservationist, is a sweetie and very accommodating.
author: Roger H.

description:
This restaurant was recommended to us by our hotel with the explanation that it was Rachael Ray's favorite. Ok, we'll give it a shot. The service was very good. Our waiter answered all of our questions on the menu, which is the most Chinese I've seen. I've never been to a place with sea cucumber and shark fin soup so I had a lot of questions.

We started with the jellyfish which was AWESOME definitely worth going out on a limb to try. They didn't have it as a a-la-carte option and instead came with a lot of other seafood, no good since my bf isn't a fan of fish. But the waiter gave it to us alone and at a deep discount, which was very nice of him. He also helped me handcraft a special dish of scallops and mixed vegetables (I love veggies and I hate having to chose only one with most Chinese food). The scallops were incredibly tender and flavorful, and the veggies were great too. This was one of the best Chinese dishes I've ever had. My boyfriend got the fried rice, it was pretty standard, but it was fried rice after all.

It was a little disappointing that at a place this nice and expensive that they didn't offer free soda refills, that's my only complaint. Great service, great food.
author: Lauren P.

description: Amazing place! I had the best general tso's chicken ever. Highly recommend.
author: Parker T.

description:
Multiple AAA placards. A gleaming "this-must-be-windex'ed-everyday" framed photo of Rachel Ray's dining recommendation. A dining room full of... well... white people. *insert cricket noise*

Off the bat, I knew my "let's stroll down into Chinatown to find a place to eat" would blow up in my face. As a general rule of thumb - one that holds true for most places - if there aren't Chinese people in the Chinese restaurant, it's probably going to be a bust. And sadly, that's what I thought about my meal. 

Thoughts?
The minced beef with egg soup was flavorless.
The salt and spicy pork spareribs were mushy and needed to be fried a bit longer. 
The steamed fresh fish with ginger, scallions and sweet soy sauce was admittedly delicious.

Ok, so it wasn't a complete bust. The fish was very good and we inhaled it in minutes.

While I leave it at 2-stars, the place is clean, decently sized, reasonably priced and has an ambiance suitable for an evening out if stuck (by choice or accident) in Chinatown. Not the best authentic Chinese food in the City but definitely not the worst.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Came on lunch break for dim sum. Portion was very small and probably the longest wait for dim sum ever. After 20 min still no food.
author: Jen W.

description: If you are looking for a Chinese restaurant with good food, good service and a nicer ambience than the usual Chinese restaurant, I would recommend checking out Oriental Pearl.   Dinner is served on a real white table cloth, so you know right away you aren't at your usual chinese restaurant.  Interior wasn't necessarily chic, but it was nice and way better than the typical chinese restaurant where you better be there for the food only.  The food was excellent (tried seafood combination in potato bird's nest, along with shrimp and walnut dish).   Service was excellent (they were there when you needed them but didn't feel like they were constantly hovering around).
author: Matthew J.

description: On a recent trip to SF (my first), I opted to stop at the Oyster Pearl on Rachel Ray's recommendation while walking through Chinatown down Grant Street. Very pleasant atmosphere, and exceptionally gracous service. The first three dishes I had were much yumminess--the taro dumplings and house special meatball, in particlar. I should probably have left well enough alone at this point as these certainly took the edge off my hunger pangs. However, I had one last snack (like the guy in Python's Meaning of Life) that I regret. It was a fried shrimp cake and eggplant appetizer. The shrimp cake was good, but the eggplant was greasy-oily and nasty. I'm embarassed to admit I ate it anyway. I was deathly sick that night, all night long. Can't say it was that damned eggplant, but I feel strongly that it was. I wouldn't avoid eating there again, and I would recommend the Oriental Pearl to you, dear reader, with the single caveat that you might want to avoid the fried dishes, or the fried eggplant at a minimum.
author: John S.

description:
We went here on Christmas night and they were "Reservations Only- booked all night".  Well we didn't have reservations, but they sat us anyways (how nice! thanks for not turning us away!!)  
We had the hot tea (so good!)
Started:
House Special Chicken Meatball-yum! (featured on the Food Network)

Main:
Mongolian Beef
Kung Bow Chicken
Egg Fried Rice.
My husband LOVED it all!  I think I would have been happier with the Chicken Chow Mein (one of my all-time favorites)

They were EXTREMELY busy (Christmas) and so the service was a bit slow, but I would definitely return again!
author: Lindsey B.

description: Fast and courteous service. Pot stickers are plentiful; Mongolian beef was tender, slightly warm but good;hubby described the kung pao a little hot, with good flavor.
author: Nicole H.

description:
So, far my favorite  Chinese restaurant. The service is always great and the food is always on par. The dim sum is good and so is the Mongolian beef and everything everyone had seem to enjoy it. 

It's kinda hidden being that you have to walk upstairs but it's worth looking for.
author: Eric R.

description: Went here for dinner last night based on reviews we saw online.  The food was very good.  We got the corn soup, peking duck (which was excellent!), whole fish ( super fresh), fried rice (very light) and chinese broccoli.  The meal was very tasty and authentic.  My kids devoured everything.  I would definitely recommend!
author: Ellen L.

description: I'm surprised this place doesn't have more reviews based on all the accolades that post both on the outside of the restaurant and on the restaurant walls.  The food is great, probably some of the best dim sum/Chinese I've had in the city. We had the famous meatballs which were so flavorful and delicate. The casing for them was egg whites...you don't normally see that, but it turned out really well. I ordered the shrimp and chive dumplings and the chicken and cilantro dumplings. They were so good and better than dim sum at the popular Yank Sing. We also had the fried rice and Mongolian beef.  The fried rice seemed surprisingly healthy with hardly any oil. The atmosphere here isn't particularly welcoming, but its about as good as it gets in China town. The servers were all really friendly, but service was really slow. It took us about 2 hours to order and finish our lunch. So if your looking for good dim sum but want to stray from the usual touristy places, this is a great option in the heart of China Town.
author: Hayley H.

description:
Decent chinese; about what you'd expect to find in touristy Chinatown. The mongolian beef was great; sweet & sour chicken was so-so; vegetable chow mein was really good; general tso's was decent. Good prices for what it is. 

You order dim sum from a menu, which is disappointing, but the quality of the food is good.

It's a safe bet. Nothing special or brag worthy, but you won't be disappointed. Feels clean and safe, which is a plus.
author: Aubrey C.

description: This restaurant doesn't look like a 3 star restaurant on the outside.  (you walk up a flight of stairs) All the staff were in collared shirts and their was a small fish tank for the kids! The food was good.  The kids liked the sweet and sour chicken. They are located in the heart of china town, right by all the shops, so it's a good place for an evening on the town. The food was a little pricey and not very memorable. Also I didn't see any locals!!! Everybody in the restaurant was a tourist. Overall I am very confident there are better places in Chinatown.
author: Pat M.

description:
We arrived in San Fran and had an itch to get over to China Town and have lunch.  We enjoyed the dim sum and a good cold beer.  The service was quick even though they missed one dim sum order (out of 3).  They were quick to correct the problem and we all enjoyed the meal.

We do not travel to San Fran often but next time, we will probably try another restaurant because we like to try variety.  If this is your first time and have no idea, I DO recommend giving it a try.
author: Chris J.

description: We went off the Zagat rating for this place. The restaurant has no ambiance, it was hot and stagnant, the waiters hurry you in and out, and the food was just okay. What a disappointment!
