author: Linda C.

description:
Slim selection of vegetarian options had me weary. The food arriving didn't help things any: soft tofu in some o.k. sauce and chow mein with veggies that taste straight out of the can... I'd have been disapointed if I paid $5 for each of those lousy dishes but they were more like $10 a peice. 

I wound up here because the guy at the bonsai shop suggested it ... dont listen to him!
author: jizzie b.

description: It's very average.  We went with a group of 6 and tried a little bit of everything.  It was all just very average, and pricey.  The wait staff was decent, and the atmosphere was okay.  Just wasn't that impressive. I'm also not a big fan of Chinatown, so maybe I'm a little biased.  See my review of Shan Dong in Oakland for a good Chinese food recommendation.
author: Tony C.

description:
The food was great.

We had a party of 6--including 2 children. We received help with ordering from the hostess. While she may seem a bit curt, her advise was helpful and made the dinner more enjoyable. Would definitely listen to her advice again. 

Since they have no children's menu, the hostess' advice was to order a full serving and have the children share (lemon chicken dish with sauce on the side which they loved).  Food is served family style so we ordered several dishes. This also let my son, who can be a picky eater, try everyone else's dishes as well. 

The tofu and green beans were phenominal. I have never had tofu cooked so well. 

Now, to find a place for tofu and green beans on the East Coast . . .
author: Kelly M.

description: My family and I visited the Oriental Pearl on Tue 7/31/12 for the sole purpose of having Peking Duck in pancakes (so many of the other restaurants offer the buns which isn't traditional Peking Duck in my opinion).  It was crispy and not greasy as some of the other reviews stated.  Very tasty and exceeded our expectations.  We also had the appetizer platter.  Afterwards, we each ordered additional dishes of chicken, seafood and vegetables which were happily shared and enjoyed.  Would definitely come here again on our next visit to San Francisco.
author: Mark L.

description:
I saw it at Food TV and wanted to try  chicken meat balls wrapped in Egg whites ! Dream food for low carb/yet yummy food lover. They are listed as appetizers and excellent. Very skillfully prepared and hold together.

But I made a even better discovery. FISH MAW SOUP. Try FISH MAW SOUP. Order the large size good for 4 people.
author: Matt Mao Tun B.

description: Overheard a concierge at a nice hotel telling a couple to check this place out, so thought it was worth a go. Really clean-white tablecloths-with good food, get the chow mein. Totally reminded me of the Chinese place I use to go to when I was a kid-pink napkins, tea in those metal pots. Good option in Chinatown.
author: J E.

description: I went to this restaurant a few months ago (my review is rather delayed) when I was visiting San Francicso. The wait took forever to get a seat, but the food was delicious. I didn't realize that the place had media exposure in the past. The service, not so great but I think the food compensated for it. This is what I call authentic Chinese food. :)
author: Angie B.

description: We got dim sum, and it was great. The meal came with dim sum, egg rolls, rice, and a dessert. All of the food was excellent, and the waitress was very attentive and helpful.
author: Sammy L.

description: Tasty place, fast service, but not the best in Chinatown I've had so far. With so many options, I'm not sure I'll be back.
author: Jessica D.

description: Went to San Francisco for vacation and wanted to eat in China Town. The food was horrible,  extremely overprice and the service wasn't any better. Will never come back and of course would not recommend it  to anybody. Go spend your money somewhere else.
author: Araceli S.

description: We do enjoy this restaurant.  It's clean.  That's sometimes hard to find in Chinatown.  The food was tasty and good.  We had the mini eggrollls, wonton soup and shared the house fried rice and the chicken chow mein.
author: D C.

description:
Rachel Ray was paid off!   First, the "recommendation" is almost 3 years-old, so at the time the food might have been tasty.  But I thought the service was slow and the dim sum wasn't much to write home about - not to mention worthy of being part of a Food Network show.   

TONS of tourists - which is to be expected, bu if I had to hear one more person say "Rachel Ray says this is the best place for dim sum" I would have drowned myself in the fish tank.

It's not HORRIBLE, but it's not GREAT either - way better dim sum to be had around the city.
author: Steven J.

description: Don't go.  I just remember going here and being disastified with my lunch, which was cheap but still not worth the money.  The waiter had BO and the eating area was not very nice.  And my Chinese colleague just went for dinner recently and reports that it was expensive and not good at all.
author: Marc S.

description:
So this is the famed Rachael Ray $40 a Day restaurant? What's so good about it? It's so Americanized that when I went in, there were only White folks eating (no offense!). I think Rachael Ray only spent around $10 here for her meal. $10 (after tip/tax/whatever) can only get you maybe two or three dishes. The food itself was below mediocre - a lot of the dumplings were ripped despite having thick skin. At least the restaurant is clean - in a hospital-ish way.

I recommend you go elsewhere for dim sum in Chinatown where $10 can really fill you up.
author: Jonas T.

description:
My husband and I were there when we were up in the city.  We really enjoyed their food and great service.  My husband and I were there half an hour before it got really busy.

Loved their Honey Glazed Walnut Prawns with steamed rice and the pan fried noodle Chow Mein.

I would recommend this place if you happen to be up in the city.
author: Cynthia S.

description: Great food. The four of us split the shrimp fried rice (lots of shrimp), half peking duck, honey glazed prawn (really good), and ginger beef and a bottle of wine and the bill was around 100. Great sit down affordable Chinese place in Chinatown.
author: G S.

description: Great service and we found the food fresh and tasty. Lot of options on the menu at reasonable prices. Clean with cute interrior. Definitely recommend. Enjoy.
author: Greg H.

description:
Impressive Chinatown Team Dinner!

My sales team was in town, and I wanted to host a dinner that would provide for an authentic San Francisco experience for locals as well as those traveling from outside of the City.  Having dined at the Pearl on several prior occasions, I thought that this may be the perfect choice.  

Turned out that indeed it was.  I contacted Rebecca, banquets manager, and she pulled together a family style menu that was awesome . . . and budget friendly.  The menu included:  Pot Stickers, Peking Duck w/ Pan Cakes, Hot & Sour Soup, Prawns with Honey Glazed Walnut, Chicken with Sugar Peas in Black Bean Sauce, Spicy Mongolian Beef, Pork with Chinese Broccoli, Oriental Pearl Fried Rice, Dessert -Sesame Ball.  We also ordered bottles of Sauvignon Blanc and Cabernet Sauvignon for each of the 10-top tables.  There were approximately 40 of us, and we were seated in the Pearl's banquet room downstairs.  This was an excellent space for a team of our size.

The food was amazing; the service was genuine and attentive.  I will certainly consider the Pearl for future team dinners.
author: Eric S.

description:
When people come to visit SF, they often want to eat in Chinatown.  I usually scoff at this, but go anyway.  Frankly, the restaurants usually aren't BAD in Chinatown, but they're not GREAT like a lot of the Thai, Mexican, and sushi joints that I know about around town.

So the concierge at the Hilton sent my uncle and I to the Oriental Pearl.

You are welcomed with an ugly sign, a torn carpet, and a two flights of stairs up to the second floor.  I actually found this to be a good sign; maybe it was a hidden gem.

The restaurant was pretty ugly inside but the waiters were nice.  The food was greasy [as expected], but actually it was very good.  We had Singapore noodles and Mongolian beef.

I wouldn't make a special trip here, but it's a great place if you're nearby.  3+ stars.
author: Rocco B.

description: Oriental Pearl was recommended by the Fairmont concierge. We walked down the hill (remember - what goes down must go up) but it is very close to the hotels and a short walk, albeit steep walk, back to the hotel. I can not say it is authentic Chinese cuisine (of course this depends on everyone's palette) but we ordered a number of dishes and they were wonderful. The Kung Pao Chicken was my fav. I always order Kung Pao Chicken at Chinese restaurants. Some do it well and some do not. It is my test. Oriental Pearl hit the target! We did not order off the dim sum menu and after reading the previous comments, I wish we had. We were greeted immediately and seated at a table even without reservations. White linen tablecloths. Amazing service! Our waitperson was delightful. Our food came out quickly - nice and hot. The restaurant is super-clean. I think this is a popular place because by 8 pm the dining room was full of a mixture of families, large groups and couples. We will return because there are many things on the menu that will need to be tried on a future visit.
author: Jillian R.

description:
I had been wanting to try this place since seeing it in Rachel Rays
40 dollars a day book. Well she was there 3 years ago and all she had 
was a special chicken meatball.
They have a poster with her fat  I mean cherub face on the entrance.
So misleading  to all the tourist and everyone else that  decides to eat here.
The food is just not good and very expensive for the low qualtiy .
Even the Rachel Ray meatball is like 8;00 dollars for one piece.
There were four of us so we tried many dishes .
Everything tasted like the kind of food you would get in a food court at the
 mall ( Panda Express ).
We tried 2 calamari dishes that were horrible.
It was like eating cut up rubber balls  covered with sauce.
The restaurant was mostly empty at dinner.
 I wish we had eaten at the ( House ) on Grant St in North Beach.
Now that's a place Rachel Ray should try........
author: Bill H.

description: I've eaten here a few times for dim sum, and it seems like the portions get smaller every time I eat here.  The same could be said for the quality.  I remember it being a lot better the first time I came here for dim sum.  The service is pretty good though.
author: Karen W.

description: Came here with my parents for lunch. We had clay pot with tofu and seafood, green beans with tofu, and my parents ordered a chicken dish.  All the food was delightful that I tasted (I tried everything but the chicken dish, but my parents seemed pleased). Total was $54 plus tip. Server was attentive and checked back on the table many times. Ambiance is underwhelming , but true to Chinese restaurants I've been to in Hong Kong.  It gives of that feel of a cheap, cheesy hotel- with the added bonus of live fish in a tank near the back of the restaurant.
author: Sam F.

description: Nothing special here. Was disappointed with the basic ha gau and siu mai. Service was attentive for an Asian restaurant though. Better tasting dim sum at the take away stores up the road (for a whole lot less!)
author: Michael T.

description:
I thought this place was awesome. After being sorely disappointed with many chinese restaurants near our neighborhood, we were happily surprised with how good the food was here. The service was great too. 

We ordered eggplant, the chicken potato nest (awesome!), spicy salted pork chops (my boyfriend was sooo pleased with these). We were happy with it all!
author: Mia S.

description: Best Chinese food!!!! Highly recommend the sweet & sour chicken, Mongolian beef, pot stickers, honey walnut shrimp!! Can't forget about the sesame balls perfection!
author: Tatiana T.

description: Best Chinese food we ever had!  Loved the Sweet and spicy shrimp and seafood fried rice.  It was so good!  I wish they had a location close to us.
author: Scott A.

description:
While living in SF, I never made my way to Chinatown.  So when my parents came up for graduation, I didn't know where to take them.  My mom, being asian and all, had her heart set on excellent chinese food.  Yelp wasn't being totally helpful, because anything that got more than two stars was not a "sit-down" type of resto.  

So I decided to trek around Chinatown with family in tow, and I don't know, "stumble upon" a resto that had a ton of people inside, because those are usually pretty good.

So that's exactly what I did.  People were filed down the stairs and almost out the door, but I was determined to get me and my parents fed.  We were lucky and got seated WITHOUT a reservation, but I think that's just because our party was so small.  

The food was just good.  I didn't get that gross, heavy feeling I often get after eating chinese food.  The seafood was fresh, not chewy like at some places.  and while nothing really, really stood out, i guess the place gets four stars because of the cleanliness and good service.

the bathroom was pristine, and smelled good.  sure, it wasn't fancy, but it was super, super, clean.
author: Angela H.

description: If you're into overpriced fancy Chinese food, this place might be worth a try.  Otherwise, there are plenty of authentic places around the corner.  Try their house special chicken meatball that looks like a dumpling.  Their beef tendon noodle soup is clear and tasty, but it lacks the depth of the 5 spice powder pack.  Moreover, the peking duck's skin isn't crispy.  Therefore, I'd pick another place no matter how long it took the chef to carve a duck out of a piece of carrot for them to display as decoration for the plate.
author: Jenny L.

description: Food is over priced. The Peking Duck was cooked well, but something about it tasted off, overall not too impressed by this place.
author: Ronny C.

description: The only time that, I went to Oriental Pearl Restaurant was just for lunch in the weekday the only item that, I tried was the beef fried rice. Another good chinese restaurant for tourist to go to.
author: William B.

description: We ended up eating here for dinner and were pleasantly surprised. Everyone was really nice. The only thing is that they rushed us to order because the kitchen was closing. We ordered salt fish, char siu bao, chow mein, beef broccoli, and sweet and sour chicken. The kids loved it all. I had done an internet search for places with good dim sum and this place didn't pop up, but the char siu bao was delicious. We tried to order more, but the kitchen was already closed. I would definitely recommend.
author: May P.

description:
YUM YUM YUM..this place has become a family tradition for us to go to (and please notice that my family is in Ecuador and in Chicago)..Their vegetable fried rice is AWESOME, their dumplings are amazing, their shrimp balls melt in your mouth, and their entrees are so well prepared that my mouth is watering right now.. 
We need a good place like this one closer to where I live, I would go there every Sunday. 
Their service is friendly and very graceful. 

Oh! Until we meet again, Oriental Pearl.
author: Mimosa O.

description: We discovered this unpretentiously spectacular place several years ago -- B.Y. -- and I've been meaning to write a review, but I'm ADD and I keep forgetting. Eleven of us were there last night. The SALT AND PEPPER CRAB is the best I've ever had, including R & G's. Each person's taste is different, though, so I want to explain why: I don't know how they do it but the crab has almost no batter, so it's a true crab experience, just you and the crab -- exquisite.  I asked the waiter what was in season and he recommended the SNOW PEA LEAVES, another delicious choice. They are famous for their CHICKEN MEATBALL, wrapped in an egg-white pancake (how do that?!), and the fame is well deserved. The staff is unfailingly courteous and your teapot will always be full. Enjoy!
author: Susan A.

description:
Oriental Pearl Restaurant
760-778 Clay Street
San Francisco, CA 
94108
 
ph# 415.433.1817
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 
The other day my bf and I went to China Town in search for the best Peking Duck in SF. We had heard good things about Oriental Pearl's Dim Sum  and so decided to give it a whirl....And it what a wonderful whirl it was!  I definitely think this is the best spot for Peking Duck and one whole order is plenty for two people.  The prices are very affordable and Rachel Ray's Show "Cheap Eats" even recommends it as one of the best spots for dim sum in SF for $40 a day.  (I am not a huge fan, but still........)
This is a excellent reccomendation as an alternative to R&G or House of Naan King.
Also, they have cuisine "to go" AND do Banquets and Parties.
I loved it....Give it a try.
author: Michele K.

description:
It's a little expensive, and yes, I feel like a tourist going here since everyone else eating there clearly is, but the food is always dependably decent. 

Maybe I have no sense of adventure, but I've had too many gross food experiences with low quality meat and greasy/syrupy/gooey sauces at other restaurants in Chinatown to risk going to too many other places in the neighborhood.  You won't have those problems at the Pearl.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
Do NOT go for dinner.  I hear they have some great deals for lunch.  But, seriously.  This place is just not a dinner joint and I may even go far as to say it's a tourist trap.  Granted, I was with tourists at the time.

The place is somewhat fancy, but not so much you  need to dress up.  The wait service was pretty good.  Attentive.  However, I felt as though the servers were only suggesting the most expensive things on the menu, not what you actually wanted.  The bill ended up being about $25 per person without booze, but with dessert.  The food wasn't THAT great.

Really.  You won't find be back here again if I can help it.
author: Chris M.

description:
I'm really surprised to see the bad reviews of Oriental Pearl.  I've been here 3 times now - once for dinner, twice for dim sum and thought it was pretty good both times.  When I went for dinner, I was with a big group so we went with pretty standard Chinese food items (e.g. fried rice, kung pao chicken, etc) that were decent.  

I think the dim sum is really great though!  They have you order off a menu instead of the carts that go around, but as a result, everything is very hot when it arrives at your table.  I think they do an especially good job at the steamed plates like dumplings, pork buns, etc.  I also think the service here is really better than 95% of the Chinese restaurants I've been to, so maybe the reviewer before had an atypical experience.  Anyway, I'd highly recommend checking out Oriental Pearl for some dim sum!
author: l c.

description:
i LOVE this restaurant. it doesn't have that necessary grime most china town restaurants have. VERY clean. staff is VERY friendly (none of that legendary chinese restaurant rudeness). 

the food is EXCELLENT. the peking duck is my favorite so far. the walnut prawns are great too. i haven't had the opportunity to go for dim sum (i'm lazy when the sun's out), but i heard that's great too.

nothing but good things about this place.
why 4 stars? it took me a while to find the place. it's upstairs.
author: Meryl Q.

description: Great restaurant for a nice family dinner in Chinatown. Atmosphere is nothing to write about but food and service were excellent! We took our server's recommendation and tried the Mongolian shrimp and general chicken- delicious. I'm not a fan of won ton soup, but it's my kids' favorite- it was really good here- delicate handmade wontons. I even enjoyed it. We will definitely come back next time in SF!
author: Heather B.

description: When looking for a place that has Dim Sum there are plenty to try in China Town but they are intimidating to tourists.  This place feels right to stop in if you haven't been to Dim Sum before.  The menu is pretty standard, the place is clean and the servers all speak English (at least the ones I interacted with).  These are key features of a Dim Sum place for any tourist.  It is up on a second floor from an inside stairwell.
author: Scott M.

description: We had n't been here in a while ( couple of years), and went for lunch today.  I don't know what happened but the quality declined.  The shripm dumpling was mushy, terrible, and the salted calamari was oily and soggy.  We had several other things and in general ,just poor quality.  Will not return.
author: R N.

description: It was lunch time, when I dined at Oriental Pearl.  The location is a few blocks away from the office buildings of downtown, so the lunch crowd didn't seem to be as plentiful as some of the dim sum places in the alleyways of downtown.  This element, I did enjoy, because the dim sum carts made their way around to us frequently, and the dining room wasn't as noisy.  The food was ok, nothing spectacular.  I believe it may even be tamed down a bit to cater to the tourists, since it's location is closer to the tourist part of Chinatown.  The pricing is resonable.  There were seven of us at lunch, and I recall the tab being realatively good, considering how many of us there were.  I probably won't go out of my way to go back there, but it certainly wasn't anything bad either, it was ok.
author: Damon Z.

description:
Randomly discovered this place searching for new lunch places at work. I must say there will be a repeat visit.

The food tastes good and prices are even better (if you order the lunch specials - $6.50 per plate). The entrance is kinda hard to find though - it's off to the side from the main sign, a few places down and up some stairs.

I'd suggest egg plant minced pork, kung bow chicken or the mongolian beef. Order a bunch of lunch specials and then share them (family style) with some friends, that way you get to taste everything.
author: Juiceman G.

description:
This is a descent Chinese restaurant that affords you a bit of elbow room and a clean restroom. I enjoy their honey glazed prawns and walnuts, mu shu, and duck. It's not bad, it's not amazing...and it is upstairs. 

Though the did give my friend Ryan the best fortune EVER!
"He loves you as much as he can, but he can not love you very much"...needles to say I almost wet myself.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Great dinners - fair on the "dimsome"
Price is right, but hey if it's good enough for Rachel Ray....
author: The Man M.

description:
My husband and I ate dinner here on the recommendation from both a co-worker and our hotel concierge.  Boy, we are glad we took them up on their recommendation because we were not disappointed!

The attentiveness of the wait staff was superb!  We never had an empty tea pot!  We had the veggie egg rolls for an appetizer...delish!  I had the Kung Pao Chicken and my husband had the General Tso's Chicken for the meal.  Both were absolutely terrific!  

If we ever get back to San Francisco, I don't think I'd eat at any other restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Kelly K.

description: The 1st time I went here for dim sum, my friend and I were shocked that we had to share a table. We were shocked more when the 6 other people at the table were also sharing the table. The dim sum here is alright and the service is very bad. When all of the parties had left our table, the host wanted to seat a 6 party family and they declined right in front of us. It was kind of embarrassing so we kind of rushed to get out of the restaurant. The 2nd time I went here, their food was actually very good. The fried taro dumplings and mongolian beef over rice were both good. But too much onions in my beef dish and very few meat. But luckily, I did not have to share a table.
author: Danster L.

description: Oriental Pearl is another recommendation from my mom.  We met my parents for an early dinner; the biggest surprise was looking up about halfway through the meal and seeing the entire restaurant filled with non-Asians!  We heard several foreign languages being spoken, and assumed the restaurant must be on a list for tourists.  Anyhow, the service was excellent and the food was very good.  The novelty of the appetizer that comes in a faux paper wrap is only worth a first-time order, though, so keep this in mind as a treat for out-of-town visitors.
author: Sherri C.

description:
This is a gem of a dim sum restaurant.  It's hidden away in an upstairs location.  The menu is very limited and everything is pretty much made to order.  It's just on the edge of Chinatown.  During the weekdays, it caters to office workers from the Financial District and some lucky tourists who stumble upon it.  You might have seen this on the older, San Francisco episode of Rachel Ray's "$40 A Day".  

The service is good and friendly.  It's a small dining room and there are no pushcarts.  It's quiet, so you can enjoy a nice lunch and conversation.  I've only been here for lunch.  The food is pretty consistent.  I like the salt & pepper calamari.  Because almost everything is freshly made, the traditional dishes, such as har gow and the shrimp filled rice rolls, are almost translucent and come out piping hot.  Portions are about right, but dishes are pricer than if you went further into Chinatown.  The quality here is much better.
author: CE Y.

description: This restaurant was recommended to us by the Ritz Carlton and unfortunately my expectations were very high and the food was pretty good but nothing amazing.  Truthfully I would've given 3.5 stars for the food, however the service deserved one star.   This is a very authentic Chinese Restaurant and they have a huge menu.  We had reservations at 830 pm and were seated on time, however, the waiter didn't give us menus until 854pm--we were starving by this time.  We ordered a bunch of dishes to share among the 12 of us and the waiter said that he may make some orders half orders so that we can try a variety of entrees in case we were ordering too much food but that we could continue to add more to our order later on.  The portions are pretty small compared to most Chinese restaurants and everything came out at different times which was annoying but appreciated because I would rather things come out hot and fresh as opposed to sitting under a heat lamp.  My husband is a vegetarian and ordered a vegetarian noodle dish for his meal and I'm pretty sure the waiter forgot about it because all of the other food was coming out and I finally asked the waiter at 945 where the vegetarian dish was and it came out about 5 minutes later (he was watching everybody else eat for a half an hour).   We wanted to order a couple more dishes because we finished everything that was brought to our table and we were still under the impression that we had one more dish coming (we ordered 2 Mongolian beefs) and when we asked the waiter he said that we only ordered one and that the kitchen was closed. THE KITCHEN IS CLOSED?!  The waiter never mentioned that the kitchen was closing and we had no idea because we tried to order more food when they put an order of fried rice on our table that clearly, someone had just cooked.  We were told that we could not order any more food and they were sorry and would give us some dessert on the house.  They didn't offer us a choice of desserts, and instead brought out 3 martini glasses filled with lychee fruit, however, this group wasn't as fond of lychees.  They finally offered to take 20% off of our bill which was nice of them, but still didn't make up for the fact that half of our party was still hungry.  All in all it was ok, but  it wast the best experience during our short visit to San Fran.  Maybe it was an off night or something?
author: S K.

description:
I went here last night with a party of 8 people.  4 of them had been there before, the other 4 had not.

In short, the experience was excellent.  We had a reservation, so we were seated immediately.  We ordered 5 of their meatballs, two orders of pot stickers, and wonton soup for the table as appetizers.  These were all quite excellent, and the waiter even served us.

For our entrees, we ordered Kung Pow Chicken, Prawns with Honey Glazed Walnuts, Chicken in House Sauce with Potato Nest, Scallops with Mushrooms, Mongolian Beef, and Singaporean Noodles.  They came out just about the same time, and I must say, they were all excellent.

However, special notice must be given to the Prawns and Chicken w/ Potato Nest.  These dishes were both incredible (there was a slight fight in who would get to eat them last).  The honey-glazed walnuts were fantastic, and I don't usually love walnuts.

Finally, the service was excellent.  Our water glasses were never empty, tea was refilled very shortly after putting the top up, and as I said, the waiter served us our appetizers and poured our soup.

This place is definitely not an authentic Chinese restaurant, but that doesn't mean that the food wasn't excellent.  And for my family, which is not the most adventurous, that can be a good thing.
author: Alex B.

description:
It's okay. Not wonderful, not bad, just okay.

My biggest problem was actually the service.  They were SUPER slow and didn't have a full restaurant.  When our entree's finally showed up, they forget about the rice.  We finally asked and it showed up, but not before sitting there for awhile trying to get someone's attention.

If you need lunch and don't care about getting the absolute best, go for it.  It's affordable, clean and okay. If you're wanting an really unique experience, look for somewhere else.
author: Leah M.

description:
This place is not one I would have found without a recommendation.  I've never been a fan of duck but their mushu duck wrap is super.  Their chicken dumpling speciality is just as good.

I'm not an expert in Chinese cuisine but I've come back here repeatedly because of the terrific experience I've had with both the customer service and cuisine.

They have been so accommodating to modify their dishes for my vegetarian guests.
author: Mic D.

description: The waiter recommended prawns with honeyed walnuts. He was spot on with that dish. It was a taste sensation.
author: Ken B.

description: Delicious food, excellent service, a real "pearl" in Chinatown. We ate here with a party of seven. Outstanding entrees were the honey walnut shrimp, Mongolian beef,  the lemon chicken, and the chicken with sugar snap peas. The Peking duck - which just was not crisp enough - left something to be desired (thus the four star  rating). The server was prompt, our food was hot and delivered course by course at just the right time, and our drinks were also tasty. Great choice! Note: be careful walking here at night - a woman was punched in the face and robbed a block ahead of us as we walked back to our hotel. Her assailant was gone by the time we got to her, but it was scary and her nose was broken.
author: D G.

description: The concierge at the fancy hotel down the street recommended this as a good choice in Chinatown.  The only way I could recommend this place is if you prefer dining on a David Lynch set.  Really, people...WTF?  Waited forever for tasteless food made out of poor quality ingredients.  I am a firm believer that you can't find good Chinese food (non-dim sum) without going to the burbs.  Why would someone be so mean as to recommend this horrible horrible place?
author: Anthony Z.

description: I really liked this place.  It was a good place in Chinatown to take our out of town guests for some good, reliable Chinese food.  The prices and service were really good as well.
author: Crystal Z.

description: Went here when my mom came into town because the reviews were decent.  Definitely worthwhile - had to go up a flight of stairs to get there, but once in, the service was prompt and friendly, the food was delicious and quick, and the atmosphere was nice.  I wish there were windows in this place, but that is such a tiny, itty bitty thing, that I can't dock them at all for it.  Awesome.  Will be back.
author: Adam T.

description: 4.893 stars! Ate here for a friend's rehearsal dinner a few weeks ago.  We were down in the separate private banquet area... fit almost 60 people in there I think.  Initially it was a hassle to get everyone seated, so the food wasn't brought out for a long time, but when it did come out... it came out fast and furious and pretty freakin tasty.  We sat at big round tables and it was tight quarters, but it was cool b/c it was a set menu and  everything they brought out, they served us (like spooned it onto our plates), they tried to get us to finish everything before they took the plates away, etc.  It was really easy... all we had to do was sit there and new food would appear on our plates in front of us.  We ate a lot there.. lots of courses.. some kind of pork dumpling, some kind of peking duck, some crab, some soup (some kind of rice porridge?), some tofu/mushrooms, some type of beef (it was like short rib type), some nice fried rice, some prawn and walnuts, there was another  appetizer I'm forgetting and maybe another entree.  It was a lot of food and it kept coming out.  We also had some kind of lychee dessert, but by that time, everyone was full.  The food wasn't amazing.. but it was very good and the service of everything was just well done.  They did a very good job.
author: Easter E.

description: I suggest the set menu, good dim sum, excellent Hot & Sour soup, Chicken & almond is very good. Good service, family friendly,The food is presented nicely, well prepared, good tasty Cantonese & Americanized Chinese food.If you expect authentic Chinese other than a few  Cantonese dishes you need to look elsewhere
author: Rodney H.

description: The food is very fresh here! In addition, the service was great! I can't wait to try more things on the menu!
author: Kamilah M.

description:
This little place rocks the dim sum.  What they lack in atmosphere, they make up for in price and yummy food!  The dim sum is really good.  The "house special chicken meatball" is something I had never had-before, really tasty. They do a great Chinatown Lunch for 10.75 a person that gives you a good smaple of dimsum and chinese food.  This is a grest place to bring out of towners when you give them a little walking tour of Chinatown (-:

The service is quick and they need you to get in and out, so don't come with you lap top and plan on camping out.

And go in even though Rachel Ray pushed it...it really is good!
author: Laura S.

description: Good food and large portions. Clean and quiet creates a good atmosphers for quiet dining. Kind of hard to find it because there is a sign past the entrance and you have to double back.  It's on the second floor.
author: Aura C.

description: We went for dinner and just ordered dim sum and appetizers. The host (who I think was also the owner) was very helpful & friendly. The food was outstanding. Everything was tasted fresh& took a little while (but not too long).  I've had Chinese food in China & this place is authentic. The entire waitstaff would come around refilling drinks. A very good experience, highly recommend it.
author: Laura P.

description: I work 1 block from Pearl Orient, and did not know it was a restaurant.  My friend who work as a concierge at a hotel took us to Pearl Orient last night and I  must say I was surprise!  The place is clean, the staff very attentive!!  The dishes we ordered were scrumptious!  My favorite is the  crab  it was mouth - watering!   Chicken sauteed with snap peas was delicious, the Peking Duck wrap was also wonderful!! Our plates were never empty!  furthermore, Charlie the manager entertained us!!  I highly recommend this place.
author: Evelyn M.

description:
i truly don't know what the big deal is about this restaurant. well, i do i think. rachel ray gave it a good review and tour guides like AAA do as well. the staff explains the dishes to you as they bring ithem to your table which is good i guess, but clearly, this is a place for non-asians. 

the place was filled only with tourists when we went on a saturday for lunch. they had their tour books out. not a single asian sitting at any of the 12 or so tables that had customers at them. we had the dim sum speacial. i could have gotten waaaaay better dim sum from any of the restaurants on clement st. for a of a lot less money. we paid about $35 for dim sum. oh well. we tried it. no need to go again.
author: BaniAndJai W.

description: Absolutely love this spot and have been back twice since moving to SF last month. Very fresh food. I was impressed at the details the waitress shared with us including which dishes have the freshest seasonal veggies (snow peas and sprouts most recently). The fried rice is excellent. The service is quite authentic, too. They bring out your dish and serve it up for you! I have heard this place was better before Rachel Ray made it a tourist destination (my boyfriend and his family dined here in the late 80s), but I enjoyed everything and will definitly return!
author: Jessica M.

description: My husband and i spent 4 nights in San Francisco and this is the only restaurant we asked for a recommendation from our very nice hotel.  We wanted to eat at a restaurant in Chinatown.  We were very disappointed.  The Dim Sum (3 styles of dumplings) was luke warm and not flavorful at all. In fact it was quite tough.  We also ordered 2 entrees, neither anything to write home about.  Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but i would definitely not go back to this restaurant.  -
author: Yvonne D.

description: Since I have some Chiu Chow in my blood, I like to enjoy some of my daddy's peoples food. I come here when I want some real Chiu Chow food. I always start with the house special chicken meatball, a delicate bundle wrapped in a gossamer pancake. I also like the pei pa tofu, peppery tofu soup with shrimp, Chiu Chow braised duck, and spicy braised prawn.
author: Juliane N.

description: I always see well-dressed white people going in here, and against my better judgement I decided to check it out.  It's definitely "nicer" and more sterile-looking than any restaurant I've been to in Chinatown, but the food was kinda bland.  It wasn't a bad experience or anything, just nothing special.
author: Rego S.

description: Rachel Ray lies!  My friends and I chanced on Oriental Pearl for dim sum one afternoon because of Rachel Ray's "$40 a day" show.  However, the dim sum was fairly disappointing and the chow fun was sloppy, gooey and salty.  One could just step into a smaller, less expensive dive elsewhere in SF Chinatown and find much better food.  I was particularly not fond of the beef rice rolls ("chong fun"), which were undercooked and under-seasoned.
author: Elaine Z.

description:
I went with my family on a weekend for lunch:

An absolute shame that this is in Chinatown. It has none of the familiarities of a dim sum restaurant. I don't mean to be a Chinese food snob, but if you go to a Chinese restaurant in SF's Chinatown, there are some base expectations you should meet. 

Service is poor, prices are high. The recipes for dim sum dishes had clearly been abandoned. Particularly any noodle-based dish - it comes out too gelatinous and congeals together. 

If you've been to a real dim sum restaurant, don't expect a similar experience if you go to Oriental Pearl.
author: K J.

description: By accident my wife and I found this restaurant.  It seemed cleaned.  But were we wrong.  We both suffered stomach aches and more.   I think it was the dim sum combination, which tasted funny.  This place is really nothing special and I question their cleanliness.  Avoid it at all cost.
author: homey j.

description: If you're in Chinatown this is a great, safe place for some good Chinese food. The friends I was with weren't fans of spicy food, so we kept it pretty basic with Beef with Broccoli, Chicken Chow Mein, and Honey Glazed Prawns. All were really good and there was plenty of leftovers for the next day.
author: Neil C.

description: Cold Sing Tao beer, crispy peeking duck wrapped in delicate pancakes bring me back to this place again and again. Prawns with honey glazed walnuts is a must try. Ginger beef and scallions are mighty tasty. They have the best pot stickers in the city. The dim sum off the menu is pretty decent. I would probably celebrate Thanksgiving dinner here if the dogs got to my turkey. I do think this place is better for dinner than lunch.
author: Fernand P.

description: I love this place. I have been their twice and both times got great food with exceptional service. Their lobster special I had the last time was amazing. There is an attention to detail here you will not find at a lot of Chinese places. The decor is not bad. It is trying to be more upscale than its many neighbors, but misses the mark a tad. A little more originality would be nice. But when I am in S.F. and want Chinese food, this is my go-to place.
author: D D.

description: Was recommended by our hotel concierge for dim sum. It was fantastic and have passed on the name several times!!
author: Nichole K.

description: The reviewer ranting about "shark fin soup" is gay... what does that have to do with the quality of the food here? Nothing. -- Anyhow, the food was good, the wait staff was helpful and explained the menu and made suggestions very well. The price was a bit high, but still the food was authentic. Be ready to drop about $30/person on dinner and drinks. -- Again, anyone b!tching about  "shark fin soup" should be permanently banned from ever again posting on yelp b/c that does not help others in reviewing the quality of the restaurant.
author: E S.

description: Great lunch special. Love the mongolian beef. For $6 you get tea, soup of the day, spring roll, salad, rice and an entre. If you're nice they'll even give you more soup.  The service is fantastic and you even get a real cloth napkin.
author: Brian B.

description: I give them a 3.5 for having decent Chinese food amongst a sea of decent Chinese food. I'm sure there are better places in Chinatown, just gotta keep moving along to find them. I really enjoy their walnut prawns and their duck mushu. It's a little on the pricier side for dinner at least, but you know you'll never be let down in terms of quality or accommodations. They are very kind, with a simple, but pleasant atmosphere, and an attentive staff.
author: Shannon F.

description: The Dim Sum is excellent. There is defiantly better Chinese entres out there. The pearl did prepare them well. Everything was tender and succulent just not  award winning. I also want to applaud the service very nice and welcoming. I gave them 3 stars but still eat there for lunch every other week. Anyone every tried sharks fin soup? Tell me about it.
author: Sean J.

description: duck was good, glasses of wine were puny, mongolian beef had no flavor, was greasy and wholly unremarkable, scallop dish had anorexic almost unrecognizable scallops, not the big fluffy white ones you're accustomed to, with those items and three beers our check was 75 dollars. so not worth it!!! staff was very nice though.
author: lindaven p.

description: Although the staff here is very efficent, and their food is good, i just think that the prices are a little bit on the higher side but thats just me. I had the beef chow fun and my friend had the salted fish and chicken fried rice, and the food was pretty good. I'd have to say this is one of the better chinese restaurants in the SF chinatown area. The only reason I gave this place one star off was because of the prices, but thats only my opinion so yeah....
author: Kalvin C.

description: I am really suprised at all of the bad reviews for Oriental Pearl. I've been quite a few times and I've never had a bad experience. I have always gone for dim sum and the food has always been good. Everything has always come out piping hot and it's always been tasty. The quality is good, the place is very clean and the service has always been better than at your typical Chinese restaurant. It may be a bit more expensive, but I definitely don't think it's pricey in the grand scheme of things. I'll continue to go to this place.
author: Anita B.

description: This is a solid establishment. Order the Honey Walnut Prawns (or something), and go for the Dim Sum.
author: Scott F.

description: In town for a conference and took the advice of a friend who recommended this restaurant. Terrific Peking duck! Excellent service by all staff. My friend and I walked around Chinatown for an hour or more, could not get a cab, returned to the restaurant and they called a cab for us! Very friendly and attentive!
author: Jann W.

description: great spot for reasonable priced chinese...made to order dim sum is good.  They also have some of the best kun pao chicken i've found anywhere in the city...just tell them to leave out the bell pepper and add extra dried chillis and green onion.
author: Raj D.

description:
Sometimes, you can't miss the stress growing inside the waiters. I suspect the owners to be rather tough with the staff. If I'm right, I must unfortunately admit that it pays, the service was excellent.

I had the menu A and based on what I had, there is one thing I don't understand. Why does Michelin recommend particularly this restaurant? I'm not saying that the food is bad but it's way below the Michelin standards I used to know. I haven't been impressed at all by what I got. I couldn't tell if the Dim Sum were homemade or Cosco-made (see the problem?). What is sure is that there are better places for Dim Sum around the bay (e.g. Hong Kong East Ocean Seafood Restaurant on a Sunday). Wan Tan soups are often blend. Here, it had the right seasoning. But, again, the wan tans tasted the industrially made. Anyway, the soup was still nice. The main course was adapted for Western people. It was a traditional lookalike Chinese food, sweet and fake. It wasn't bad. And I can't blame them for adapting their meals for locals. It's just that I know that better Chinese restaurants can be found in SF and this stupid Michelin thing made my expectations too high.

Oh, and a last thing, can Yelp ask bars and restaurants to stop using this sugary yellowish lemon flavor syrup for cocktails? It's disgustingly wrong! Instead, they can use Teisseire (dilution 7-fold).
author: LawAai V.

description: a friend wanted to go here cause Rachael ray suggested it.  i hardly call this place a Chinese restaurant.  it was way too clean to be a dim sum joint.  and where was the carts?  no dim sum carts here.  the food was okay.
author: Jo T.

description:
The Concierge from our hotel made us a dinner reservation at The Oriental Pearl Restaurant and assured us it was where they send all their guests.  I explained to the Concierge that our child has allergies and he said that this restaurant was extremely accommodating.  We arrived five minutes early, were seated and immediately explained to the waiter (who understood English) about our daughter's eating allergies.  (We also presented a card in Chinese if there was a language problem)  He assured us that it was not a problem and told us what could be eaten.  We ordered appetizers, the waiter then came back and told us that he made a mistake and our daughter could not have the soup or chicken dish.  We reordered and he then came back and said our daughter could only eat the rice and vegetables as they marinate ALL of their fish, chicken, meat......in advance in a sauce that she cannot eat.  After 30 minutes we left the restaurant with our child in tears.  We have never been treated like this in any other restaurant before.  If in fact the restaurant could not accommodate us they should have told us that when we first entered the facility and we would have left and been grateful that they told us they could not accommodate us.  However for this "game" to go on for 30 minutes was absurd.  I find it difficult to believe that every single piece of protein in the entire restaurant was pre-marinated.  Any restaurant the "pre-marinates" all of their protein in the same marinade is certainly not tops notch and not a caliber that should be referred to others.  
I do need to mention however that prior to this debacle, we ate at two different Chinese restaurants that we walked into off the street in China Town and they were very gracious.  They not only were able to but they prepared anything our daughter wanted with ingredients that she was able to eat and enjoy
author: Maria B.

description: We went in because it was one of the first ones we ran into... and the fact that they had Rachel Ray's photo and the Michelin Guide's review on it sealed the deal.  The food was pretty good and fairly priced.  It really caters to visitors as we were able to communicate effectively to the entire staff.  I usually like dim-sum restaurants where they come around in carts and you can point at what you want, but since it was pretty easy to order from the menu, the food came out straight from the steamer/oven piping hot and delicious, and may have changed the way I like to order my dim-sum.  Pretty good, although next time, I'd probably venture a little deeper into Chinatown to the spots where they don't speak English and yell at you in Chinese... those are supposed to be the best and most authentic ones. :)
author: Del N.

description: This is the restaurant I send most people to and always get the best feedback.  I love their prawns.  This Restaurant and R & G Lounge I think are the best in China Town.
author: Antony E.

description: If you don't know Chinatown well, are looking for a place to eat Chinese food and may be scared because you don't have a good recommendation from anyone, this place is a safe bet.   Food is decent, place is clean and the staff speaks english.   I was pleasantly surprised and given I had low expectations, it exceeded my expectations.
author: Val V.

description: I went back to Oriental Pearl for Chinese Newyear and a couple weeks after that.  The service was as friendly and attentitive as always and the food top notch.  The deep fried prawns with spicy sauce were greasless and crispy with a tongue tingling, lip biting sauce that was like a spicy sweet and sour sauce to be exact.  The Oriental Pearl fried rice is dry and firm with fresh shrimp, flavorful Chinese sausage, and meaty mushrooms which make for a wonderful plethora of flavors.  The rice noodles with duck and preserved vegetables are aldentae with slightly chewy but gflavorful duck meat and fresh vegetables.  The barbecued quail has a smooth, liqured exterior and moist interior.  AS far as more dim sum is concerned, the deep fried taro dumplings are a little greasy, but not by much with a meaty, thick, and starchy and salty taro and ground pork filling.  The deep-fried squid with spicy salt is crispy with ever the slightlest greasness and a one-two punch of a salt and pepper coating over the entire squid.  The pan-fried shrimp and chive dumplings are crispy on the bottom and gossamer omn the top with suculent whole shrimps and savery chives.  The day that I was there two weeks after the Newyear parade, one of the waitresses gave us a free order of tjheir flaky, buttery, smooth, rich egg custard tarts.  Oriental Pearl is definitely one of the few good remianing restaurants in Chinatown which will stand the test of time.  Once again, keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.
